reviewText:
Rayman Legends is quite possibly the best 2d platformer released in the past 10 years.

It‚Äôs the follow up title to Rayman Origins (also a great game) and if you missed it, 40 of the stages from Origins have been included in Legends as additional re-mastered content.

It features over 120 different stages each with varying atmosphere, amazing music, and plenty of hidden collectibles. Each of the levels are hand drawn and beautiful to look at. Despite not being overly impressive on a technical level, Rayman uses a timeless style. While games like Crysis 3 probably won‚Äôt look that great 10 years from now, Rayman Legends will no doubt retain its charm.

The game also has multiple characters to choose from along with a host of unlockables. There are underwater stealth missions, time trials, and even musical stages where you jump to the rhythm of remixed popular songs. The inclusion of daily and weekly challenges allows you to compete with your friends, adding tons of re-playability.

If you enjoyed classic 2d platformers like Super Mario World and Donkey Kong Country, you should check out Rayman Legends as it‚Äôs the closest thing to them in this day and age.

For a more detailed review, here‚Äôs a video my friend and fellow reviewer Trent uploaded:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=195783687

Rayman Legends also made our list for The Top 35 Games of the Generation. If you‚Äôre interested in seeing how it stacks up, check out:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DWIHmom_lP4


If you enjoyed this review, feel free to follow me as a Steam Curator: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/4886473/

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Out on a limb
Rayman seemed to find his limbless arms and feet after the release of Rayman Origins - a beautiful and intoxicating adventure of a game that turned out to be one of the most unexpected surprises of 2011. Taking Rayman back to the drawing board, Ubisoft and series creator Michael Ancel took the bold decision to steer the series back to its 2D roots with the introduction of a new framework called UbiArt that simply has to be seen to be believed. Through the use of UbiArt - Rayman Origins became the closest game this past generation to get the actual look and feel right of a Disney movie or cartoon come to life. It was also a wise decision because it helped differentiate the new game in a 3D platform dominated AAA arena.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=340572257
With its tight, razor-like controls harmoniously married to the games increasingly frantic series of precise jumps, runs, kicks, swings, slaps and air glides, Rayman Origins was an absolute delight to play and a joy to handle despite almost reaching Super Meat Boy levels of frustration towards the end. So... after years of roaming the platform desert (where many a failed platform hero is sent out to die) the genre suddenly had a new unsung hero. Had Rayman finally arrived at the gates of Mount Mario ready to take his place in the pantheon of platforming gods?

Everything about this sequel is larger, funnier, livelier and more joyous than the first. It's also bat-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• crazy in the same way one would expect an asylum to be when that asylum has been taken over by the nut hounds themselves. Legends goofy story pretty much picks up where Origin left off with our friends once again awakening from another 100 year slumber only to find out that the mad magician from the previous game has split into five dark magicians who are once again running amok releasing nightmares of all kinds into the Glade of Dreams and its mythical lands beyond.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=227755791
Yet again, the nightmares and the magicians have gone on to capture all of the teensies along with the 10 princesses that rule this delightfully wacky world and it's once again left up to Rayman and his mad, zany cohorts to save the day. Like Origins - the game starts out deceptively easy but ramps up the difficulty pretty fast becoming rather super-duper difficult towards the end and will rely on lots of precision timing in order to complete. You will need pixel perfection to complete this adventure and if you don't mind that, you are going to have a blast and some seriously good laughs along the way.

I really admire Michael Ancel and the team he put together to create this platforming adventure. The levels of creativity on display in Legends far surpasses the surprise and wonder from Origins as they disassemble the traditional platformer yet again and in the process create what I now consider a platforming masterpiece. Coupling this with some of the most intensely satisfying level design and music they really have gone on to create last generations platforming masterpiece. If platformers get any better than this - please direct me to it because quite frankly this is the new gold standard in my books.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=340572690
If I have one gripe - its a large one but thankfully the games generous and loving heart is so huge it has swayed me not to deduct from my personal rating - is that is still does not offer online co-op. In this day and age this is a major oversight on Ancel and his teams part. I would want nothing more than to experience this zany adventure with some of my close friends who don't happen to be sitting on the couch with me but alas I can't. Like the Lego games from Traveler's Tales this repeated oversight is starting to make them look like stick-in-the-mud's and I hope that with the next release they seriously consider making this an option because I won't be so kind the next time around. If you are a platformer, cartoon or - hell, even humorist enthusiast you owe it to yourself to own this game immediately.

Welcome to the pantheon Rayman - your seat is the one next to the Italian Plumber with the red hat!

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
Rayman Legends is a truly special game. Following the fantastic reboot of Rayman Origins, Legends surpases it in every way possible. The tight controls and superb level design makes gameplay smooth and fluid. Every death feels like a fault of your own and not the cause of a cheap obstacle or bad game design. Add to this the best visuals and art direction of any platformer ever (yes, including Trine 2), and you have a recipe for greatness. The UbiArt engine is able to produce such lush and wonderful artwork that it's hard not to stop at stare.

As for content, this game has more than enough. Boasting a sizeable amount of main stages as well as Origins redone. Throw in the time trials and daily challenges, this game will surely satisfy any platformer fan.

Although it may seem hyperbolic, I believe that I can say with certaintly that Rayman Legends is the finest platformer that I have ever played. It's the complete package. If you are a fan of the genre at all you owe it to yourself to pick this title up.

reviewText:
After playing Rayman Origins I thought there's no way there could be a better Rayman game. I was wrong. Rayman Legends is even more beautiful, more fluid and better in a lot of ways than its predecessor.
The art style is similar to Origin's but brings little improvements that make it seem not only pretty but also chiseled from a tech point of view. It definitely looks like they took their time with the visuals of Legends, when you have to improve on something as good as Origin's art style it's the details that make a world of difference.
The difficulty can vary depending on how thorough you want to be with the collectibles - and there's a lot of them: lums, teensies, trophies for getting them as well characters/costumes getting unlocked because of it. The game can be enjoyed by anyone, it's never dull even if you don't decide to got after those though to reach collectibles.

Pros:
+ beautiful
+ technical for collectibles
+ great campaign pacing
+ those music levels
+ couch co-op

Cons:
- no online co-op

reviewText:
I'm going to start this review off by saying the only negative thing about Rayman Legends is Uplay, which if you haven't yet experienced it is basically the worst thing since the invention of the Vuvuzela. That said, I'm not even going to let Uplay hold me back from giving this game the amazing review it deserves.

If you like platformers, you're going to love Rayman Legends. Simply said, it's one of the best platformers ever made and,  as someone who really loves platformers, I don't say that lightly. The artwork is beautiful, the soundtrack is incredible, and the game is just non-stop un-adulterated fun from stop to finish that you'll have a hard time putting it down. I logged more time into this game that I've ever put into any game short of Pokemon Silver version before I'd even realized I'd been so long. The amount of content that this game has to offer is astounding, especially considering almost all of it is utterly fantastic.

Normally I'd give the message to boycott anything and everything that runs through Uplay but - just this once - I'll have to make an exception, because if you don't play this game you're missing out on something truly wonderful.

reviewText:
one of the best platformers ever, puts Rayman origins to shame, this game has tons of extras to unlock. there are some amazing classic hit songs in some stages (won't spoil the surprises on you ;) ), the score is awesome and the art style is top notch, high production values all around.

in case you didn't play Rayman Origins, the game is basically run from point A to point B to finish the stage, of course there are many hidden secrets in every stage and many things to collect to be able to unlock the other stages and progress through the game, it has a lot of variety and always interesting that you won't be able to put the controller down, there are many things that will spice up the game like in some stages you need to run as fast as possible to finish, some stages you will have a companion to help you out by raising up platforms or cutting ropes for you..etc.

the main game tends to be a little easier than origins but it still lots of fun and there are many challenges to be had if you want to, there are also a few stages from origins that made it to this game

the multi-player co op is frantic and funny as in origins, you will be laughing all the time at the crazy things that you can do when playing it with 3 other players

and then there is the mini game called Kung Foot, a crazy football game which requires you to slap or kick the ball and make it hit your opponent's goal, it might sound simple but it is really fun and you might get a lot of hours just playing this mini game.

well i think that should be enough to make you buy it or at least give it a try, it really is amazing and it is really scary how much content this game has and if you are a fan of platformers, believe me you will enjoy this game for sure

reviewText:
Rayman Legends is just so much better than Origins. I remember talking, erm.. not so positive,.. about Origins. aside from the wonderful, colorful graphics. Well, let me say that Legends is a bigger and better game in every way; customization, unlockables (oh man, they keep on coming), secrets; there seems to be much more variety this time around and I couldn't recommend this game more.

There are 6 worlds to be completed, with the last one being more of a bonus world. Each world has about 8 to 10 levels, and each level could you take at least 5 minutes to complete. So it's a big game. Add even more secret and unlockable levels to that number and you know why it's called Legends.

Each of the first 5 worlds end with a musical level where you just run, punch and avoid enemies based on the music. It's brilliant and it works very well. In general there's much more variety gameplay wise as well, with the aforementioned musical levels but there are also stealth levels, and levels where you have to rely on a (CPU controlled) co-op partner.

The animations and graphics are top notch. Rarely have I been as impressed with 2D visuals as I've been with the last few Rayman games. No words can describe how this game looks and plays, you really have to witness it for yourself. This is art !

By the way, the boss fights aren't as frustrating as the ones in Origins. There was only one boss that, in my opinion, was more of a trial-and-error boss fight, the rest of them could easily be beaten the first time around, if you pay enough attention.

Rayman Legends surprised me in a big way and I'm saddened to hear that it didn't sell all that well. It has tons of content, so much even that most games look empty in comparison.

Buy it. Cherish it. Love it. Play it. But, more importantly, enjoy it. How can this game not put a smile on anyone's face ?

[Rating: 92/100]

reviewText:
Rayman Legends is a 2D platformer that features hand-drawn/hand-painted graphics¬†and well-known platformer hero, Rayman and his friends.

Rayman Legends is one of those bright and colorful games that takes players through lush jungles and underwater caverns. There's alot of diversity in this one and although there's no story, the game is entertaining enough to keep your attention span throughout it's entirety.

Simplicity is the game here. You basically run, punch and jump through enemies or obstacles. You have a slide and can duck but you don't use those mechanics as much as you think. You also have a glide funtion to help you reach further platforms.

Tons of characters, extra levels and pets to unlock means that the game will gove you plenty of hours of light-hearted joy but that's not all, online functions give plenty of additional content for you to dig into. There's everything here from time-attacks to rescue missions.


Pros  Lengthy single-player campaign
Smooth animations
Fun and sometimes hilarious soundtrack
Co-Op/Multiplayer options
Tons of unlockables
Daily challenges and weekly challenges, every one is unique, no 2 challenges are alike
Endless replay value
Mini games
Full controlled support
Cons  No storyline, no explanation to characters or where they originate.
The main campiagn may be too easy for some
Getting all the lums and bonuses in the levels may become tedious
Final Thoughts:
One of my favorite platforming games on Steam or in general, it's also one of the few platforming franchises that has stuck to it's gameplay roots. I always had great fun with Rayman games from the PS1 days to the 3DS craze and this one is no exception. If you like straight up 2D run and jump platformers, give it a try!

Rating (7.8 out of 10)

This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

reviewText:
This is what sequels should be all about. Taking mechanics that worked from the first title and buffing them to a mirror finish, and then introducing new ideas to make it original.

For me, Origins was a really, really fun and solid game and a great return to form for the Rayman franchise. I've sunk many hours (three digits) into it and, despite not being the completionist type, have been pushed to try quite hard to do so by it's captivating art and great soundtrack, plus pile of content. With Legends, Ubisoft has managed to recreate this gem, but better. It's as simple as that.

The UbiArt engine is slick at all times and always stable, the game is even prettier then the first and, somehow, even more tuneful. I haven't anything to complain about yet, except perhaps that it's not occasionally as brutal as Origins in spots, but there's always plenty more in the game, and I haven't even mentioned the online challenges yet where the player competes against a global leaderboard.

If you like platformers, you'll probably love this game. It's fast, it's competitive and is sensibly integrated into online challenges, and doesn't suffer very much from being originally WiiU exclusive. It's my favorite game of 2013 (previously a title given to Revengeance), and a perfect 10 in my books.

I do recommend picking up Origins before this one if you're a newcomer to the franchise, though. You will simply be missing out otherwise and it has come down drastically in price.

reviewText:
Ill be honest here. Ubisoft has create some very discouraging factors for players to even buy this game.
It has unnecessary DRM that forces you have installed Uplay and steam at the same time to just play the game. This is a rather rude concept when i speciffically purchaced the game on steam and want to keep and play my games on steam.
A online multiplayer could had made this game a huge hit for many years and instead we get one of their ppl tell as excuse that he likes it local because you cant hit other ppl online... really? I could see a endless line willing to slap him for that.

Still, the developers did manage to safe this game by making it simply amazing from graphic and gameplay to amazing level design.
The game allows you to play also the levels from Rayman origins but has also many bonus mini games that unless you are really bored, you wont probably play those much.

Multiplayer makes most games more fun but doesnt have effect on the whole playtrough so single player is just fine.

Pc controller work fine in my case.

So if you like quality games, you are a rayman fan and can tolerate Ubisofts flaws then the game is definitely worth it

reviewText:
I love platformer games.  They're such a nostalgia blast, taking me back to the old days where I was parked on the living room floor, 5 ft. from the TV trying master that epic double jump without falling in the hole for the 10th time in a row.  Rayman Origins came along and proved that that old school platforming action could still be viable, fun and challenging.  Now, Rayman Legends has managed to come along and actually improve on the foundation that Origins laid!

Rayman Legends packs a ton of fun in one single package.  You have unlocks to collect, in the form of lums, characters, monsters and even old Origins levels.  You have challenging platformer action.  You have varied platformer action!  You have a great sense of humor.  You have a great art style to make it all shine.  It's really great.

Sometimes, games of these types reach a point where the game becomes too difficult.  It makes the experience nothing but frustrating and then the fun falls off fast.  Even Origins suffered from this from time to time.  In Legends, they've managed to find a perfect balance in the difficulty.  Most maps are challenging, without becoming anger inducing.  You might have to take two or three tries and a particular jump, but the pattern will click.  These types of games can also suffer from repetition, but Legends break that up as well.  You'll find the puzzle style changing from level to level, even within the same groups, keeping the game feeling fresh and entertaining.

Beyond all the platformer action, I'm really impressed with the style and art direction going on in the game.  The end levels in each section doing something really great in how the tie in the games music with the game play.  This really stood out when I was playing a boss level to a Rayman-esque rendition of Ram Jam's Black Betty".  As I came to obstacles
date: it because clear my jumps were timed to the drum beat of the song.  As you progressed
hoursPlayed: you noticed the entire level was timed to it.  I couldn't help by smile and play the level over a couple times
voteText: just to marvel at the fun of it all.  They do this on every level and it's an attention to detail that you don't see to often!\n\nSo
helpfulPercent: should you snag Rayman Legends?  Yes.  Yes you should.  Don't even debate it.  Really
votesHelpful: this game is worth it at any price.  Definitely bring your game pad though
votesTotal: I can't imagine pulling this game off with a keyboard and mouse.\n"

reviewText:
I have always had a soft spot for 2D platformers and this is probably my favorite of the genre at the moment. It has got bright colorful graphics, great controls, interesting level design and it offers a good level of challenge without being unfair or frustrating, something Rayman Origins often missed the mark on.

The main part of game world is divided up into 5 different paintings, each with 9-10 levels based on different theme.  The paintings all end with a boss and a musical level, where the action in the level follows the background music. I loved the musical levels and I wish there were more of them. There is an extra unlockable painting that let‚Äôs you play the musical worlds again with added challenges, but it is basically the same level.

The game has tonnes of content with invaded levels, daily/weekly challenges, and you can unlock most of the levels from Rayman Origins. You certainly get your money‚Äôs worth here.

Honestly the only caveat for this game is Uplay...I have had issues with it in the past and I know many people continue to even today.

To Ubisoft‚Äôs credit, over the last 3-4 years they have taken Uplay from being an unusable piece of malware to more of an annoyance. So let‚Äôs give them credit for that, I guess‚Ä¶

My advice is just log into the Uplay application once, set it to offline and never, ever, touch it again.

reviewText:
Make your life legendary
Rayman Legends is the sequel to the critically acclaimed Rayman Origins, with Legends taking what worked from Origins and refining it.

Pros:You no longer have to unlock powers separately, meaning those who‚Äôve already played through Origins can experience the entire moveset from the start.
A fantastic artstyle that‚Äôs a lot more shinier and polished than Rayman Origins.
A large pools of fun and great levels, backed by good level design.
Additional modes like Challenges and Kung Foot help make the experience more replayable for both local co-op and singleplayer gamers!
Surprisingly well optimised for lower-end computers!
Nitpicks:The bonus ‚ÄúCreatures‚Äù element of the game is completely unnecessary
Being locked out of certain levels in the challenges mode by a leveling system is frustrating
Online Multiplayer would had really made modes like Kung Foot more popular.
The levels containing Murphy feel a lot more repetitive than normal, although at least they aren‚Äôt auto-scrollers.
Cons:For a mostly local cooperative game, there‚Äôs no excuse for this to require Uplay., even if it has a lot of somewhat unnecessary online activities.
The Review
As someone who grew up playing Rayman, I adored the return-to-form that was Rayman Origins, and Legends continue the trend with new levels, shinier graphics, and a ton of additional packed goodies.

Rayman Legends is a mostly 2D platformer with a lot of collectathon elements, but it‚Äôs great to know that collecting all of the teensies is much a major requirement, which allows for speedrunning. There‚Äôs a huge amount of levels to play, and since you aren‚Äôt restricted in playing all of the worlds in order, you are given a lot more freedom to tackle levels! The return of 4-player co-op is good fun, although it quickly devolves the game into a chaotic mess, so completionists are better off playing alone (Which is still fun!).

Gameplay for the most part, is as refined as Rayman Origins. The controls are responsive, and your moveset is versatile but simplistic enough that you are given a lot more control. It‚Äôs actually really difficult to talk about this game because of how perfect controlling the characters is. The physics, the button layouts, it just feels so natural. However, for keyboard players, I highly recommend picking up a controller to play this game, as with other platformers.

The newest mechanic in Legends is of course, Murphy. By the press of a button, you can have him slap switches, tickle enemies, and cut ropes. For the most part, however, Murphy‚Äôs only included in some of the levels, which I‚Äôm perfectly fine with because Murphy feels heavily gimped from the Wii U version.

As someone who‚Äôs 100% complete the game on Wii U, I‚Äôve noticed huge differences between this version and the Wii U one as well. For one, there‚Äôs no 5 player co-op, or the ability to have complete control over Murphy. Both versions seem to trade one thing for another; The Wii U version allows complete control at the cost of not having direct control over your player in single-player mode, and the PC version lets you control your character, but have more limited control when it comes to Murphy. A good middle between the two would had fixed the problems, but both versions are stuck with the levels containing Murphy being either a slog or being quite the unintentional challenge when speedrunning/completing comes to play.

The reason why Murphy levels feel weird in the PC version is because they were designed to be slow-paced, which makes them unintentionally more difficult now that you have full control over your character and can freely run.

The game includes a wealth of side-modes to play, and while they aren‚Äôt anything to write home about, they are nice additions. Challenges make for a unique set of leaderboard challenges that‚Äôs constantly reset weekly (although a lot of the challenges are the same things from past rotations and can get repetitive), and Kung Foot is an insane blast to play. However, the addition of a XP bar to lock challenges and the ‚ÄúCreatures‚Äù addition seem to be completely unnecessary, and only serve to make 100%ing this game feel more like a chore. Also, Online Multiplayer would had really helped when it came to modes like Kung Foot, because I can‚Äôt really get my friends together all the time to play it.

Presentation-Wise, Rayman Legends nails it. While I like the more zany look of Rayman Origins, Legends polishes up the artstyle to look completely unique and beautiful. When certain enemies or objects are shown as a 3D model, it doesn‚Äôt look odd or unusual, making it a solid blend of 2D and 3D visuals. It‚Äôs music is a joy to listen to, despite being dangerously close to being generic medieval fare. The UI mostly doesn‚Äôt distract the player, although the constant in-game notifications definitely are annoying.

So how‚Äôs the PC version of the game? Surprisingly good! I managed to get it running 60fps on my laptop (which seems to like running games at terrible framerates), and it‚Äôs been doing superb for me on my main PC (to no surprise). If you have a low-end computer, you should give it a shot, it isn‚Äôt as intensive as it looks.

Unfortunately, the game requires uPlay (which is weird because Rayman Origins didn‚Äôt!), and it‚Äôs as big of a mess as always.

TL;DR - Rayman Legends is a fantastic platformer with splendid controls, tons of bonuses, and a stellar presentation. It‚Äôs still my GOTY of 2014!


For more reviews on all sorts of games, follow  Lots' o Giveaway's group curations and reviews  here!

reviewText:
This game is impressively good. If you like Jump'n'Runs / Platformers you really should give it a try.  I managed to collect all possible 700 Teensies and I never had the feeling that I have to go on just to finish it, which sadly happens too often to me nowadays. I think it's easier than Rayman: Origins, which could be seen as one of the few cons. Especially the Back to Origins levels felt less challenging than the originals.
The art-design is superior and the graphics look just great. It's crazy, bright and funny, but not too childish to be not appealing to mature audiences. Surely, you have to like that type of style and humor. The same goes for the sound, great work!
The levels are greatly designed, not too long not too short and enough variety to keep it fun to play. It has challenging parts, which never are too hard and can always be mastered with some tries. Fortunately, the checkpoints are set really fair, perhaps making it a bit too easy.
The music-levels are a highlight of the game, you run through a level to a song, while your jumping, attacking and the whole level architecture is timed to and built for the music.
The daily and weekly challenges are nicely made and keep you going after you finished the rest of the game.
I haven't played it with local multiplayer, but that also looks fun.
While the game is such a great one and really conquered the throne of 2D-Jump'n'Runs for me, the only really big letdown is the usage of Uplay. Since you can buy it on Steam, why the hell do I have to use Uplay for online features. I can't even change my username! Sadly, I realized this after I connected Rayman: Legends and Farcry3 to it, with something like: username: uplayaccount ‚Ä¶ -.-

Conclusion
*Story: Well this is not the biggest part of the game, it's OK, nothing special but it doesn't need to be.
*Gameplay: Great! Fluid controls, impressive varied levels, lots of stuff to unlock, online challenges
*Graphics&Sound: Superior! I really love that style, not too childish but funny and crazy

I give it 95 out of 100

Side note: I played the game with maximum graphics fluidly and with a controller.

reviewText:
Rayman Legends takes what was established in Rayman Origins and improves it. The vector graphics are back and look prettier than ever, there is the addition of a sidekick as well to help you get through some levels.
There is a lot to do in this game, each level has 10 teensies to find (The little blue guys), as well as the challenge to find enough lums (The yellow flying guys) to earn the Gold trophy. There are also unlockable characters as well, collectable creatures, unlockable bonus levels from Rayman Origins (each has teensies and trophies to collect) and Time Trial levels as well. If you're a bit of a completionist like I am with these sorts of things, you'll have lots to keep you occupied. There is also the new music levels, which are very much like the chest chasing missions in Origins, completely timing based where you jump or attack in time with the music. These are excellently thought out and the timing is spot-on. These are a bit more forgiving than Origins' chest chasing missions though, having checkpoints rather than making you restart after each death.
There are downsides though, this game is a console port and at times it shows, making some actions hard to perform using keyboard if you don't have nimble fingers. It is perfectly playable with the keyboard though and supports full key remapping (Which I suggest you do, I set mine to the Origins controls and it saved me a lot of trouble), but it may be easier to play using a controller. I can't say which is better, since I've only played using keyboard, although you can play one handed using keyboard, leaving your other hand free to do other stuff like eat a sandwich or write a book. It also doesn't really have much replayability, apart from the music levels which are awesome just to play occasionally, unless you are a big Rayman fan. Plus it only works through UPlay, which is not a bad piece of software but it does make things frustrating when you just want to get right into the game.
Overall, this game is worth picking up, even at full price and the annoying DRM. Graphics are pretty and there is a lot to do. I'm really looking forward to the next game in the series,
9/10

I can't belive that i didnt picked this game earlier up.
One of my steam friend bought it for me, i can't thank him enough.

I'm now currently at World 4-2. So far everything that i saw was absolutly fun, cool and i could play these levels over and over, just because they are so ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• awesome.

One thing that this game makes it so cool is the fact of the humorous and jokes this game has to offer. Want to play as a duck? Wanna see a random giant wrestling guy falling from top to bottom just you can go on? Or do you just want to hear a plant singing by slapping his eye?
Then this game should give you a good laugh.

Gameplay: Nothing here changed since Origins, which i also played too (Wiii Version). I feel like Legends is easier then Origins. I had my problems getting progress in the previous game, probably because i was back there a child which had nothing better to do. Also, the levels from Legends are in my option better, but it's also cool to see that you can play the previous levels from Origins, i really like that.
Bosses that i had to beat were top. My favourite one HAS to be the 3rd boss.

The biggest feature are the music levels. Diffirent covers from songs, like from Black Mary, Eye of the Tiger and so on. I NEVER had so much fun playing these Music Levels. They are completly new and fresh also. if some DLC's were avalible, i would defendly try them out. Also Castle Rack has to be the best one.

Soundtracks: Some soundtrack from Origins were re-used, but that doesnt matter. The soundtrack is often outstanding, is fitting really good in the currently situation you are in. I was imaging i were in a mission impossible in World 4-1, damn that was perfectly.

Challenge: I never had the experience yet to be in a trial and error section. Otherwise, the game isnt too easy, and isnt too hard.  Mixing the difficulty perfect together makes an awesome game experience.

Overall, this game is it money worth. Buy it now if you can!  Trust me! You will never have more fun then playing this!
10/10

reviewText: Rayman Legends, a game that was supposed to be Wii U exclusive on February 21, 2013 and Ubisoft decides at the last second to make it multi-platforms so it was moved to September 2013. I honestly have played all the versions of this game but i only own the Wii U and PC version. Rayman Legends is a sequel to Rayman Origins where this time, instead of saving happy faces, you save the usual Teensies like in most Rayman games. There are multiple characters to play as even though there all the same. Gameplay is good however, when your playing Murphy levels, you cannot tap whatever you want unlike the Wii U version. This is frustrating since you cannot get some extra lums for a gold trophy. Every level has 2 objectives, get a certain amount of lums and save teensies. You cannot progress furthur until u get the right amunt of teensies. There are other modes in this game like Kung Foot where its basically soccer. There are also Challenges in which you do a certain objective everyday. There are 4 types of challenges: Daily.Daily Extreme,Weekly, and Weekly Extreme. The maps also change once its been a day/week and a diffrent objective like how far can you go or how fast can you get a certain amount of lums. You do get trophies for this which raises your Awesomeness level. Your Awesomess Level increases as you collect trophies as they give you points. Once you reach a certain amount of Aweomess, you unlocked all the challenges. There is also a lottery and to get tickets, you need to get a certain amount of lums in levels.\nI give this game 7 out of 10 because this game is literally meant for the Wii U, Plus the Wii U version has more content than the other versions like being able to control Murphy which is really good.

reviewText:
I have to say, this is a pretty inspired platformer. The controls are simple, power-ups are few, but instead you get treated to some seriously well designed environments. The daily and weekly challenges are a testament to how much gameplay variety the game has. There are enough background touches that replaying a level a few times, you'll notice things that you missed the first time through. The musical stages are a treat for the eyes, and a nice homage to the early auto-play ROM hacks (i.e. SMW Kumikyoku) which would do the same thing. (though you need to jump and fire to the beat, of course)

You don't have a lives counter. When you die, you just start back at some arbitrary checkpoint. You can also just opt to restart at the last checkpoint via the pause menu if you messed up getting some collectible. (lums or teensies) Challenge purists may scoff at this feature but anti-frustration features such as these are long overdue. Some players go for utter perfection and they can still impose that challenge on themselves. Those of us who'd rather not endure dozens of repeats of an entire stage for one difficult section will have things the way they are. Not to mention, anti-frustration features are much more kid friendly. Finally, Ubisoft cycles through challenges every day where you can compete with the world. They have you covered, though they admittedly do a miserable job at managing the hackers.

The game is fairly non-linear, with paths opening up as you collect more teensies and lucky tickets.  Teensies make more standard stages available, and tickets (eventually) open up more of the Back to Origins" stages.

90% of what I _didn't_ like about this game can be summed up in one word: UPlay. The fact that they're using steam as a conduit to push their redundant DRM system which significantly adds to the startup time is appalling. One thing you better not do is check the box that says "don't tell me again" when you close the window with your key. You won't have the steam overlay available to get it again when it's time to enter the key again
date: many minutes later. I almost botched my install this way...luckily I hadn't copied something else into my clipboard. This experience alone almost caused me to knee-jerk a negative review in...lucky for them
recommended: the game is extremely good.\n\nThe rest of what I found irritating were some of the pop-ups after a level. One made it look like an option but literally forced me to stop what I was doing and go play an invasion level. I also kept getting annoying popups to use the tickets even though I'd already responded to one such popup. It's my own damn prerogative if I want to use them all at once. I also don't like the fact that unlocking levels is somewhat RNG based
hoursPlayed: but I'm guessing that they had the sense to heavily influence the "randomness" of unlocking said levels.\n\nAll in all
voteText: I guess I recommend it. Hopefully someday Ubisoft will realize they're alienating gamers with their DRM
votesHelpful: I'm sticking with Steam. Thanks. That said
votesTotal: the game itself is worth the annoyance."

reviewText: If you're the one for nostalgic games, including Rayman, then this is the one for you! The gameplay is superb, and although it does lag a tiny bit now and then, you won't even care because you're too focused on how fun this game is. ;) Some levels require fast thinking, multi-tasking and being quick on your feet (Rayman feet) as you jump through obstacles and fight off enemies that come in your way whilst a fire blaze is coming after you. There are also lever-related levels where you have a handy sidekick guy who helps make your obstacles a bit easier, as long as you remember to use this little sidekick guy by pressing 'w', or 'q' and 'e' to make him rotate the wheel/s. Furthermore, there are mini games such as challenges, and a sports ball-kicking multi-player mini game. Throughout the game, you'll have little bonuses popping up here and there to help you gain more points/life, and during the game loads, there may be a free life-line heart which you must grab before the loading has finished (if you want to!). You also must try to free all of the little blue guys (in some or all levels) in order to gain all three trophies for each game room. Overall, from a Rayman lover, I think this game is worth the buy, especially since I was able to get it 75% off (special sale). You won't regret it, and like I similarly said, you will have so much fun once you get into the grip of the game.

reviewText: This is the best platformer I have played in many years.   The art style and overall ambiance enhance the game experience instead of hindering it, the music perfectly matches the levels (especially the musical themed levels), and the controls are very tight.  There are so many levels to play and they are the perfect length, not too long or too short, with checkpoints on each screen transition, making some of the harder levels fun to master, instead of dreadful.  Once you beat certain levels and reach a certain level of collectibles, levels unlock that are tougher than the main campaign for those seeking challenge (they usually have time limits which require perfect control or else you will not reach the goal).  The steam version also has the previous game (Rayman Origins) included, but require unlocks to play.    For those who love platformers, this is a must-have game.

reviewText:
This game is pretty great. If you liked Rayman:Origins, you'll like this one. If you don't have Origins, you don't really need to buy it, since this game contains almost every one of the origins levels as bonus levels. It's a great idea, and they're fun to revisit.

If you like fun, cheerful platformers with good music, good controls, and a good difficulty curve, you'll really like this game.

However, unless you really enjoy pain, I'd recommend finishing the main levels and quitting.
By the time I realized that was what I should have done, I was close enough to 100% that I just soldiered through, but it really left a sour taste in my mouth in places.
One of the best parts of Rayman:Origins for me was how the difficulty ramped up through the whole game, culminating in the Land of the Livid Dead. Those levels were monsters, but practice and a bit of luck would see you through, and man did I feel accomplished when I beat them. You needed every single trick you'd picked up in the game, and maybe a few more, but they weren't unfair, just brutal.
Rayman:Legends on the other hand, has a land of the livid dead that's not new, it's not interesting, it's just selected levels you've already beaten with hideous graphical filters over them. Pixelating them, adding pulsing static and other visual noise, oh, and removing the checkpoints. Two of them gave me hideous headaches.
Just for that alone, I'd have to say Origins is the stronger game.
Legends also adds a whole bunch of timed mini levels, some of which can take dozens of runs if you're trying to rescue all of the smurfs that have been captured. Some of them are a nice break, but having so many of them makes the magic run dry very quickly.

I'd also like to know why there are ~40 unlockable playable characters when there aren't appreciable differences between them. Not sure what the point there is.

Anyway, overall, this game is in places good, even great, but for completests, it's a bit of a kick below the belt in the places it should really shine. I recommend it, but with the caveats mentioned.

reviewText:
Here I was thinking Origins would be the best platformer I ever played... I am so happy I was wrong.

Featuring a beautiful and lively hand-drawn world of wonder and expansive variety, your eyes will thank you for all of the stunning visuals this game has to offer.  Gameplay feels absolutely perfect, even with Murphy being programmed to a single key.  The levels feature plenty of challenge, abilites and indeed the famed music levels that will make you want to scream in exitement with every perfectly synced note.  Speaking of notes, you'll be hearing a lot of them from the same composer that wrote Origins' music... which means yet more astonishing scores to be experienced on just the soundtrack, since Cellos played as bass guitars are BADASS (look up Dive another day" or "Lost in the Clouds").  Even after you reach 100% completion there are still new daily and weekly challenges to keep you coming back for more.

You'd have to be out of your mind to think you can get a better platforming experience on PC anywhere else right now
date: it's an absolute no-brainer.\n\n*NOTE: THIS DOES REQUIRE UPLAY

reviewText: This game is the sequel of Rayman Origins and the fifth canon game of the franchise. Superior to Origins in everything, it features lots of improvements since graphics until its gameplay. Although it isn't better than the first three games of the quintology, this title is superior to Rayman Origins and it brings back fourty levels from it with adapted gameplay mechanics and slightly improved graphism, but the return of the RO levels might make the experience feel repetitive. Sadly, the story isn't quite improved either, it is a game that mostly focuses in gameplay. Despite of this said problems and other particular ones, it is still an enjoyable game and recommended especially to people that still didn't have the chance to play Rayman Origins. Recommended.

reviewText:
When you pop in this game, the first thing you notice is the poor edging on Rayman, the main character of the movie and the main character you control in the game. The Rayman Legends movie was done with Silicon Graphics Computers‚Ñ¢ and the instruction booklet says the game's graphics were created with the same 3D computer models used in the making of the blockbuster movie.

We don't know however if the game uses Silicon Graphics Computers‚Ñ¢. If SGI Computers‚Ñ¢ were used, we suspect they were only used for character animations because the backgrounds do not have the detailed quality graphics of Donkey Kong Country. As any good dedicated game-player knows, Donkey Kong Country was created with Silicon Graphics Computers‚Ñ¢ and doesn't have edging problems.  Whats even more strange is that  Rayman is the only character with edging problems. All of the other characters look great.

One question remains, why didn't Ubisoft use Silicon Graphics Computers‚Ñ¢ for the entire game? Were they too expensive? I don't think so. Come on. Big Ubisoft is one of the richest corporations in France. Let's get real here.

Bottom line, Barbara is cute.

reviewText:
I bought this game a long time ago. Before I started writing these reviews nobody reads. Today I decided to reinstall this game  because I needed some inspiration, as I make games on my spare time and I remembered this game as one of the most amazing looking games I ever played, then write a review nobody will read.

Every screenshot is an artwork. But visuals anyone can tell how good it is by looking at the videos and screenshots, so I'll move on and talk about the rest of the game. By the way, if you're into art I also recommend googling Rayman concept art and get to know Aymeric Kevin's artwork, the artist behind it.

Now that I started writing this I realize I don't have much to say about the game. There is nothing new to be analyzed; you jump and attack through the levels. So I'll put it like this: imagine the best 2D platformer you ever played, it's likely done by a small team, indie. Now imagine if that game had the amount of polish a triple A game  usually gets. That's Rayman Legends. Every second on it seems to have been crafted by a hundred skilled hands and playtested to exhaustion. It's so well paced that at times it's challenging without being frustrating, at other times it's easy without being boring. At the end of each chapter there's a musical level where you run and jump as you do in bit runner and other rhythm running games, and it's so fun I was laughing out loud while playing. Laughing because you are having fun is not something I'm used to. Laughing of a good joke? sure, but it's not the same thing. It's a super nice variation from the previous levels and it does feel like a reward for beating every level. This is something we always want as gamers, rewards for beating the game. It's why we watch the whole credits and absorb every bit of extra content we have. In the old days we would examine every pixel of those static images of the end game credits. I feel like These musical at the end of each chapter gives us exactly what we want. An explosive and fun reward for all the work".

Also
date: it's not every day you see a reboot light years better than the source material. It baffles me every time I remember what the original rayman was like.\n\nIf that's not obvious by now
recommended: I quite like Rayman Legends and I recommend it."

reviewText:
This is the best platformer I have ever played. Take everything great about Rayman Origins and make it even better. All the great stage design, boss fights, and challenging difficulty is back. There is so much content in this installment of the Rayman series. Online challenges, remastered Rayman Origins stages, Local Co-Op mode with a fun minigame, Time Trials, creatures to collect, characters to unlock and a ton of awesomely designed stages in the main section of the game. There is also a nice statistics screen to keep track of all your progress.

There are online challenges that change on a daily and weekly basis. Every player in the world competes in them and gets ranked by how well they perform in the challenge. You can also race against the better ranked player's ghosts. It basically shows exactly what they did during the challenge, while you are playing. You can also increase your trophy level by placing high in lots of challenges and clearing portions of the game.

The music themed stages in this game are probably my favorite platforming levels in any game ever. Playing a whole level in sync with the music feels very satisfying. There are also a ton of other stages that are amazingly designed. The boss fights are very satisifying to play. The Time Trials portions of stages feel perfectly designed for running through them as fast as you can. There is quite a bit of depth in making your character move as fast as possible in all situations. These Time Trials make you realize how fast you can actually go.

I have spent around 40 hours to 100% the game and do some of the online challenges. You can probably spend around 30 hours just to 100% the game and around 20 hours trying to complete the levels. Some of the levels are very hard and the online challenges have sections that are even harder. They bring back portions of the Land of the Livid Dead from Rayman Origins for some of the online challenges. You can also play a lot of the Rayman Origins levels in this game, but they have been remastered to make the levels a bit better designed.

This game has everything you could want in a platformer. It is highly recommended and I don't think you can find a better designed platformer game than this one. Go buy it now!

reviewText:
Mario ain't got nothing on Rayman Legends. Slamming music, tight controls, eye-bleedingly astounding art direction, 4 player-same-screen-co-op on PC. Show up for the charm and amazing aesthetics. Stay for the super-hard-core platforming action. RESCUE ALL THE TEENSIES!

Hands down one of the most finely crafted platformers I've ever come across. You owe it to yourself to check out Rayman Legends. Just make sure to rebind Murphy's context button. It's horribly placed. =D

However, there's a pretty big asterisk to this review: Like most Ubisoft games, this game requres you to maintain a Ubisoft Uplay account in order to run the game. I don't care, personally, but a lot of people are turned off by draconian DRM measures that Ubi has put in place. Making matters even more confusing, Ubi is evolving Uplay into its own digital distribution platform ala Steam. So it's like Steam-ception. It's a Steam within a Steam, albiet a Steam that is geared towards Ubi's publisher proclivities. So, to recap, you have to download a digitial distribution service through your digital distribution service in order to play the game. Like I said, doesn't bother me, but I know it sure as hell bothers a lot of people.

reviewText:
I have always been fascinated by the Rayman series because of the good graphics, but I never liked the games very much and never related in any way to the main character. However, giving this newest part of the series a chance was a very rewarding decision. The developers did nearly everything right in my opinion:

gameplay - just great, you have perfect control over the character and a lot of different moves, in part depending on your environment

amount of content - the game is really exemplary in this respect: multiple playable characters, a huge amount of levels and additional daily and weekly mini challenges that remodel certain areas

difficulty - even though challenging at times, the game always seems to be fair and does not lead to a lot of frustration (and I played all the locked and hidden levels)

design - the graphics are beautiful, especially the vegetation and the sci-fi stuff. the level design is very good and keeps you entertained with varying design elements and a lot of funny and crazy ideas

sound - the sound effects and most of the music is great and original, sometimes very atmospheric, more often very funny. some of the tracks could have been better suited to underline the atmosphere of certain areas. the music-themed levels (in which your movements have to be in line with the music) are awesome in general, as is the music for the underwater levels

In sum, I can really recommend this game to everyone who likes to play platformers. Even If you only like some of the platformer classics, but stopped playing that type of game for a long time - you probably should give this game a try :)

reviewText:
Context:
Well polished and rich game, reminds me of the rich, unique, original and well polished work that used to come out more often in the past, caring so much about the finer details that make a game a universe of its own.
Considering how the CoD and AC series were initially at a such high level of quality, especially the first releases but later declined with every sequel. It is therefore a surprise how Ubisoft with its overall declining quality, managed to produce such a great quality work with this one. Could this mean the same for its other series? Only time will tell, since as Ubisoft has shown here, it's never too late to get back on track.

Some snippets from the game itself:
+This game as many others have mentioned, is suitable for all ages and is great for gathering friends and family in playing such a fun game cooperatively or competitively.
+Every level is unique on its own, giving a different flow, challenges and experience to every level, this is one of the major factors that make the game so replayable.
+Small details regarding playable and non-playable characters in their movements and reactions to the envirnoment, which are so well made that not only do they truly give an impression of the personality of the character, but aids in making the gameplay experience so fluid.
+Manages to instill an actual sense of achievement, versus a ton of modern games that reward 'achievements' without the actual sense

Minor negatives:
-Requires Uplay which constantly and forever will have sync issues with achievements or saved games. (I never needed to backup saves for Rayman, but for AC:Unity and Sleeping Dogs, which overwrote my progress, I needed to backup my saves constantly mid-game)
-Only local Coop +Counter: However this encourages getting actual persons to play with you in the same room, which enriches the experience. Also, there is an online score ladder, with other player's ghosts to compete with in the weekly/daily online competitions.

Rating: 9/10

Amazing game. I've loved the Rayman series for it's immersive gameplay and unique style since the announcement of Rayman Origins. Ubiart Framework is a fantastic studio and I just adore this game like no other. The game is quirky and fun, you'll notidce that little is serious about this game when you play it. It's comical and charming all together. Fans of Rayman Origins will definitely enjoy this game. It has a lot more features than Rayman Origins had-In this game you collect Teensies, there're 10 in each level, and how many in each painting varies. In the invasion levels, and other specific levels(such as bosses or music levels) there're 3 teensies to collect. Each level is just an epic immersion into the marvels Ubiart Framework can achieve with their technology. The music is phenominal, it adds dynamic to the overall gameplay and allows the player to truly get into the game, and the E3 press conference mostly emphasized one of the music levels-but it's not just the music levels that have great music. The entire game has a beautiful soundtrack that truly adds to the game's feeling. I only have a few complaints about the game...Some of the invasion levels are merciless and tedious. For one level I spent a good hour trying to get it just right to earn all 3 teensies. The levels are put together awesomely, but the spike in difficulty of invasion levels sometimes takes a toll on gameplay. If you're a perfectionist, it becomes more of a chore than something fun...But it feels great once you do get it just right. The daily and weekly challenges always add a spice to the game, allowing for players to earn more lums for completing various tasks in certain levels, it helps keep things fresh, and it definitely made me come back for more because I always wonder what's going to be the challenge for today. In this game you recieve lottery tickets after earning so many Lums, which is pretty cool-but you can also earn 'creatures' for your creature gallery. I never really understood the creature collection. They supply lums daily, but otherwise they don't seem very collectible unless you just, you know, like to collect them(personal opinion). Overall this game is amazing. It's worth every penny,

Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.\n\nGameplay: Rayman Origins was a very fun and generally very well designed game, if slightly flawed in certain areas. Rayman Legends is a very fun and generally very well designed game, if slightly flawed in certain areas. It's the same old-school" platforming experience delivered in Rayman Origins
date: but this time it's delivered just a bit better. Gone are some of the absolutely infuriating and sometimes unfair memorization-heavy levels (for the most part; I'll get to that later). Out of the core five worlds
recommended: there were really only three levels that I wasn't too terribly fond of. For a game that has about 40 levels in the core worlds
hoursPlayed: that's quite good. In fact

There is also a portion of the game called "Back to Origins
votesHelpful: which is essentially a best-of collection of levels from Rayman Origins. Again, most of these levels are pretty good, but it just seems lazy to me to only bring back some of the levels, rather than bring back all of them. They've essentially given us all of the good stuff, leaving us no reason to go out and buy Origins. Much to my annoyance, they also brought back the boss fights from Origins, which are the aforementioned unfair memorization-heavy levels. They were the worst part of Origins in my opinion, but they are not the worst part in this game.\n\nThat honor" goes to the Livid Dead Party world

If you like torture and pain, if you like failing tens and hundreds of times in a row, if you like dying whenever anything touches you, if you like repeating the same area over and over again until getting the perfect score, this is the game for you. It contains so many challenges that it's hard to count them all.

Lack of Steam achievements (well, at least Uplay achievements work) and online co-op and cloud saves, extremely slow startup of Uplay, no instructions on advanced moves, issues with servers* and other drawbacks are annoying, but I can bear with it because it's one of the best platformers ever. Before the resurrection of Rayman, AAA platformers were dead and the genre was left to indies. I'm immensely delighted that I can play Rayman now and small annoyances won't stop me.

The game contains levels from Rayman Origins, but you should still buy the previous game because the gameplay has been serously changed. Graphics have been upgraded, but new remixes are not as balanced and perfected as the original levels.

P.S. Music levels are AWESOME.

* Server and connection issues may vary depending on your location. There are also some bugs with country/server detection.

The best Rayman since Hoodlum Havoc. It has a great art style (Like Origins but with better shading and lightning) maginifecent music, perfect controlls, 120 well-made levels, and daily/weekly challanges!  Go buy it!

You don't know Rayman until you play Origins, you REALLY don't know Rayman until you play Legends. Rayman returns to kick a lot of butt in this game. So many levels to play, characters to unlock, activities to play, and bosses to fight. Since this game has Uplay, you are able to play with other Uplay people and friends who have a Uplay account in Multi-player battles and challenges. Leaderboard and all, not only do you play the levels, but they have daily and weekly challenges for you to play. Seriously this will keep me busy for months. You don't know the Legends until you PLAY the Legends!

If you like torture and pain, if you like failing tens and hundreds of times in a row, if you like dying whenever anything touches you, if you like repeating the same area over and over again until getting the perfect score, this is the game for you. It contains so many challenges that it's hard to count them all.

Lack of Steam achievements (well, at least Uplay achievements work) and online co-op and cloud saves, extremely slow startup of Uplay, no instructions on advanced moves, issues with servers* and other drawbacks are annoying, but I can bear with it because it's one of the best platformers ever. Before the resurrection of Rayman, AAA platformers were dead and the genre was left to indies. I'm immensely delighted that I can play Rayman now and small annoyances won't stop me.

The game contains levels from Rayman Origins, but you should still buy the previous game because the gameplay has been serously changed. Graphics have been upgraded, but new remixes are not as balanced and perfected as the original levels.

P.S. Music levels are AWESOME.

* Server and connection issues may vary depending on your location. There are also some bugs with country/server detection.
Amazing for local co-op play!

Amazing game. I've loved the Rayman series for it's immersive gameplay and unique style since the announcement of Rayman Origins. Ubiart Framework is a fantastic studio and I just adore this game like no other. The game is quirky and fun, you'll notidce that little is serious about this game when you play it. It's comical and charming all together. Fans of Rayman Origins will definitely enjoy this game. It has a lot more features than Rayman Origins had-In this game you collect Teensies, there're 10 in each level, and how many in each painting varies. In the invasion levels, and other specific levels(such as bosses or music levels) there're 3 teensies to collect. Each level is just an epic immersion into the marvels Ubiart Framework can achieve with their technology. The music is phenominal, it adds dynamic to the overall gameplay and allows the player to truly get into the game, and the E3 press conference mostly emphasized one of the music levels-but it's not just the music levels that have great music. The entire game has a beautiful soundtrack that truly adds to the game's feeling. I only have a few complaints about the game...Some of the invasion levels are merciless and tedious. For one level I spent a good hour trying to get it just right to earn all 3 teensies. The levels are put together awesomely, but the spike in difficulty of invasion levels sometimes takes a toll on gameplay. If you're a perfectionist, it becomes more of a chore than something fun...But it feels great once you do get it just right. The daily and weekly challenges always add a spice to the game, allowing for players to earn more lums for completing various tasks in certain levels, it helps keep things fresh, and it definitely made me come back for more because I always wonder what's going to be the challenge for today. In this game you recieve lottery tickets after earning so many Lums, which is pretty cool-but you can also earn 'creatures' for your creature gallery. I never really understood the creature collection. They supply lums daily, but otherwise they don't seem very collectible unless you just, you know, like to collect them(personal opinion). Overall this game is amazing. It's worth every penny,

While the side scrolling genre may not have the same mass appeal it when decades ago, this game is a perfect execution of what is possible for the style.  It is also beautiful, full of variety, and always fun.  Masterpiece!

You don't know the Legends until you PLAY the Legends!

This is one of the funnest platformers, and maybe the funnest game I have played in 2013. Everything flows smooth like a hot knive through butter. The graphics and art are even better than Rayman Origins, which looked great also. The bosses are fun and the music level are the best part of the game in my opinion. Just try to see if you can guess each one. I have only played through the first 3 worlds, but they have been fun and amazing. Definatly worth full price, but if it goes on sale, BUY IT IMMEDIATELY!!!
Fun levels that give you hours of entertainment, personally I prefer a controller for easy movement. A lot of cool things to do, definitely worth buying!

Rayman Legends - A really fun and well polished platformer
Overview:
Maybe it's just because I love platformers, but like Rayman Origins I absolutely love this game, even if it can be frustrating.

Pros:
Great fun with loads of levels, including those from Rayman Origins
Runs really well
Doesn't feel hindered by the fact that it was originally going to be a Wii U exclusive
Great fun for local co-op
Cons:
Unlike Rayman Origins, Legends is not DRM free and requires Uplay, which can be annoying if you use Big Picture
No online multiplayer

Platformers. The beginning of my dive into video games was Super Mario Bros. I've since played most Mario, Sonic, Mega Man, and countless other platform games over the years. I have an extensive history with them.

Based on that, I have to say that Rayman Legends is one of the best I've ever played.

- The controls are very responsive and the gameplay just flows effortlessly from move to move making it your own fault if you screw up.

- The art style is amazing and is something I will never tire of looking at.

- Extensive number of very well designed stages that are extremely fun to play

- Time Trials, Daily and Weekly challenges, and most of the stages from Rayman Origins can be found here.

- Musical stages, where you run and jump to the remixed beat of popular songs. I play these over and over they are just so enjoyable.

Basically, if you don't already own it, buy it. Yes it requires Uplay, but so what? The game is so darn good, I honestly don't see why it matters.

recommended: but the later unlockable levels and "invaison levels" will be a severe challenge. Overall a fantastic game."

reviewText: The first Rayman game I played was on my iphone and I enjoyed it so much, that I thought I buy it on my PS3. A friend of mine lend me Rayman Origins and it was good. When I saw on Steam Rayman Legends for sale I bought it straight away and I have to say its one of the best games Ive played. I grew up with 2D platformers like Mario and Sonic, I played the New Super Mario Bors on WiiU but its no match for Rayman. Rayman is in my opinion the best Ubisoft Game and the best platformer hands down. It has so much content - unbelievable. Here you can even unlock the levels from Rayman Origins - so basically you have two Rayman games. The later levels are challenging but not unfair thanks to well placed auto-saves where you dont have to restart the whole level - which is fair because I think I wouldnt finish some levels, or I would have to play them till I retire. It has a very high replayability value and is definitve worth the money even on full price. The next Rayman game I will buy right when it comes out - im looking already forward to it. An by the way, the graphics are cool but the music is just awesome - especially the music levels. Love this game - go get it!!!

reviewText:
Rayman Legends definitely lives up to the old style of Rayman games, with a little more extra features than the older games.

It features over 120 different stages each with varying atmosphere, amazing music, and plenty of hidden collectibles. Each of the levels are hand drawn and beautiful to look at. Despite not being overly impressive on a technical level, Rayman uses a timeless style. While games like Crysis 3 probably won‚Äôt look that great 10 years from now, Rayman Legends will no doubt retain its charm.

There are underwater stealth missions, time trials, and even musical stages where you jump to the rhythm of remixed popular songs that'll have you laughing stupidly hard at how at first you won't understand what's going on but quickly have a hard time playing because of the nostalgia that hits you as you go further into the stage. The inclusion of daily and weekly challenges allows you to compete with your friends, adding tons and TONS of re-playability. The weekly challenges come with leaderboards so you'll always feel accomplished having topped a certain percentile in the gaming community.

The community is great, many of which have turned into speed gamers for this game.

8/10
Non-stop sidescrolling action and adventure in an animated world. Visuals are immersive and crisp. Game scales from too easy to very, very hard. Worth checking out (especially when on sale).
Very well designed game! Has a very unique rayman vibe to it, very fun and challanging at certain points while remaining quite casusal too. Overall a great addition into the rayman series!

reviewText: The best platformer i've ever played. It's genius from the word go.. the payoff levels at the end of the worlds are fantastic additions. Everything just screams quality and it's obvious a lot of care was put into making sure the game flows smoothly. Amazingly enough, it also has a great soundtrack to complement the action, it feels really organic and changes seamlessly to suit what's happening on the screen. As a nice bonus it even features the best levels from the previous Rayman title, itself a modern classic.\n\nThis is a seriously underrated game here, the only drawback being that it may be a bit too easy with unlimited lives and no timers. That doesn't bug me at all though and there are more than enough challenges and baubles to make up for it.

reviewText:
A sequel to one of my favorite platforming game (Rayman Origins.) Legends surpasses Origins in every single way. It looks better, it plays better, more characters, more skins, and it has more levels. You can even unlock some of the original levels from Origins to play on the new engine.

You don‚Äôt see many AAA platformers released on PC anymore, and it‚Äôs a shame because Legends is just a joy to play.

I love the music levels at the end of each world. It‚Äôs truly amazing when you have each step and action sync up to the song playing in the background.

One of my complaints is that there is only local co-op. There is no online multiplayer available.

Legends is a must play for anyone. If you‚Äôre still on the fence there is a demo to download.

reviewText:
So I was excited as I could've been for this to come out, seeing as how Rayman Origins was proabably my fave 2D platformer in a long while.
It was on the day when this became available for preorder that I noticed it had mandatory Uplay DRM. I swore not to buy it at full price, let alone preorder it, solely because of that fact. I would not be the one supporting DRM in my DRM, no sir.
I eventually bought this more than half off and found out that there's no option to disable gamepad rumble, and do believe that I loathe rumble.
After having muttered some Ubisoft addressed swear words I started playing and...  I forgot about my well-founded self-rightous hate in all but a few minutes. It's slick, intuitive and responsive, the sound design is one of the best you'll ever find and the graphics are sure to make you widen up your eyes on occasion.
Do I recommend getting this game? Of course I do. Do I recommend getting this game on Steam? Not necessarily.

reviewText: Rayman Origins has the benefit of being DRM-free (even on Steam) and cheaper. Rayman Legends has the advantage of more varied levels, enhanced graphics (although whether or not they're actually better is debatable), more characters, and... containing most of the levels from Rayman Origins as unlockables. It also has the disadvantage of being tied to Uplay for pretty much the sole purpose of the daily challenge feature... which has to date not worked for me even once.\n\nIf you can stomach Uplay (which I have had more than my share of issues with, personally), it's the better game, and an ace example of platforming.

reviewText: I'd never played a Rayman game before and so I had absolutely no idea what to expect when I started up Rayman Legends for the first time. Man, was I ever pleasantly surprised! It's truly one of the most fun games I've ever played. While not particularly deep from a gameplay perspective, good humor is bursting from every seam and it's impossible not to be swept along.\n\nThe level design is perfect and the visuals are utterly spectacular. I find myself playing just one more level" to see what incredible visual treats the game has in store for me next. I also have to single out the game's remarkable composer
date: Christophe H√©ral. Music is as integral to the experience here as it was in classic Warner Bros. cartoons. You may find yourself replaying certain levels again and again just to enjoy the wonderful soundtrack. Of particular note is the fact that many of the tracks were recorded using a full orchestra
recommended: something which is very rare in games these days. Huge kudos to Ubisoft for being willing to spend the extra money to get such high quality results!\n\nIn conclusion
hoursPlayed: Rayman Legends is pretty much a must-have game. I think gamers of all skill levels

reviewText:
This title was a complete surprise for me. I did not expect this game to win me over like it did, but its aesthetic and its polish are unbelievable. This is a must buy for any fan of platforming games. This is the culmination of decades of creating platform games, and they nailed it.

-The game looks absolutely incredible. There are 3D elements tied into the 2D perspective and they really did an amazing job with it. The game is VERY colourful and looks super crisp on my monitor at 1920x1080.
-The game runs like a dream, no problems there. The graphics settings are rather limited, however.
-The game features precision platforming but at times it becomes a spectacle-platformer of sorts
-It incorporates very creative ideas in its level design, including rhythm courses where your actions sync up with the music - this was incredible. I had a smile on my face the entire time, it is a must play, or at least a must watch on YouTube.
-The game is very deep, with tons of unlockable heroes and weekly and daily challenges, etc. Leaderboards are very prominent. The replayability of this game is unbelievable.
-I HIGHLY reccomend you play this game with a controller. It is doable on keyboard with some keybinding adjustment required, but I much prefer the controller.

I cannot say enough about this title! Must-own.

So it's like, pretty good.
It doesn't flow like Origins because this game makes you stop every 8 second to get something, but it's still fun.
It seems to be universally agreed that this game is easier than Origins, which I don't understand, because after playing the demo for Origins 300 times (Give or take) I can go through that game without dying once, yet this game kicks my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.
The artstyle is somehow improved, which surprised me, because looking at the screenshots in the store page made me think they'd gotten worse. But the art is a lot better, anyway. Here's one of those stupid pro/con lists that makes it all easier for you to digest.

MLG PROS:
-It's bigger than Origins.
-It looks better than Origins.
-Apparently debatable, It's harder(?) than Origins.
-The game still controls like sliced buttered asscheeks.
-That water level with the spy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.
-I LIKE COLLECTING THINGS
-Daily/Weekly Challenges.
-Murfy's Dungeon.
-The level design, is actually pretty good.
-I recommend this game.

CON ARTISTS:
-Murfy.
-The level design won't let me go as fast as Origins. Winners go fast.
-I'm running around in a castle and suddenly end up in the desert of didgeridoos? WHERE AM I?
-Murfy.
-That feeling I get when I see Murfy's face on a new level's painting.
-Getting 1,000,000 Lums will make Rayman strip.

reviewText:
Cartoon graphic? Yes gimme!

A worthy sequel to Rayman Origins, a true blast playing the game. Despite the uPlay plaguing the game, but I'll turn blind eye just because the game's bloody awesome.

Still maintaining the old Rayman mechanic. You jump, you punch, you run. Some of the mechanic is truly comical for example using your partner to tickle the enemy so he raises the spike shield so you can hit it till dead. Welp, only in Rayman maybe.

I also like the daily challenges where you compete with other players as 'ghosts' to beat a series of... challenges. From collecting items as fast as possible, to clearing enemies in a screen. Frankly this provides a new end game for players that have beaten the game - and it's a cool thing to have.

Level designs are just neat. Well yes, cartoon, but who cares. All designs are just perfectly blend together. There are varying degrees of levels' difficulties that require you to time, mostly jumping from platform to platform to collect gold rings/items, but it doesn't hit you with frustration. Regular enemies are mostly easy, you just need to be a bit more careful and don't get too excited to finish a level to actually smash the enemies with your Rayman body not punch. Ew.

Performance wise, I'm running the game with my weaker VGA and it runs silky smooth. No question asked, no complaint, unlike many games nowadays that require patches (and the excuse of 'so many hardware configurations out there!'). Well done Ubisoft, well done.

So grab your controller, hit some bad guys and play this awesomesauce game now!
