reviewText:
NOTE: this review is written by a person who doesn't have any sentiments for Rayman having never played original Rayman titles on PS/PS2.
i did, however, play previous Rayman game, Origins, and it was great. truly, a 5-star platforming experience. when i found out that there is a sequel on the way, i was all over it.
i was playing on the launch day already, in fact, the two of us were. it's a great title to have fun while playing with family or friends and i highly recommend.

(pros marked with '+', cons with '-')

+ GRAPHICS.
gorgeous, simply gorgeous. it was hella hard to beat the look of Rayman Origins, but Legends managed to do it. what's amazing too, it's that it has considerably low requirements for what it is, i play it on Intel HD Graphics completely fine.

+ CONTROLS.
works wonderfully, as you would expect from a game that has pretty difficult time attack levels.

+ LEVEL DESIGN.
platforming is amazing, it's tons more fun to do local co-op in this one. fighting is easy, but then again enemies aren't supposed to challenged you, they're rather obstacles in this game, similarly to barricades.
my only gripe with level design is time attack/rush levels in co-op - the player who is slightly faster will always activate some events that lead to another player dying, at least we couldn't find a way around it. maybe it just requires being in complete sync, hehe.

+ SOUND/MUSIC.
music by itself is amazing. it's quite different from Rayman Origins, which had also had a stellar soundtrack, but while the first one was cutesy pitched-up singing, in Legends we platform to cinematic/orchestral top-notch quality music.
special mention: musical levels are best thing to happen to platforming in a good while. Castle Rock is the best level in any platformer i ever played.

+ CONTENT.
there's quite a lot to do.
collect 700 teensies - and it is pretty fun to do it. main levels have 8 (6 scattered across the level, 2 found in special puzzle rooms) in them, with time attack/rush/boss levels each having 3.
collecting lums net you lottery tickets, which are a fun side activity - they unlock collectable creatures and also remastered levels from the previous Rayman game, Origins. yes, they are gated between the grind, as in you have to collect enough lums in each available level to get a ticket to get a chance to unlock a level, but without trying to get a maximum rating we easily unlocked more than 16 remastered levels by simply beating the levels.
5 colourful words, each having two additional character unlocks, a boss level and a musical level. 6 world, as a bonus one, contains remixed musical levels. strangely enough, those are quite nauseating to play because of the fish-eye effect.
there are lots of other unlockable characters as well.

+ DIFFICULTY CURVE.
Origins had one very annoying feature, or rather, lack of one. proper checkpoint system. often you had to redo way too long sections of the level, especially, if you missed a Teenie, and that was one of the reasons we couldn't finish all levels from it. i feel like Rayman Legends, while easier overall, is a good balanced game, and much, much less rage-inducing that it's predecessor.

- STEAM INTEGRATION.
yes, that is a con for me.
i'd have loved getting achievements from this game. i'd love trading cards and background art for my profile from this game. i think workshop could have been pretty wonderful too, you know how many amazing talented people are there in the mod community.
i must mention the uPlay thing. i hate being forced to use their DRM on top of Steam. it's unnecessary. and i'm never going to spend money on a platform, that is trying to force itself on me. i bypassed uPlay requirement in my own version, so i'm missing out on the leaderboards, but so be it. i don't consider this to be a fair requirement to begin with.

- MINOR PORT SYNDROM.
well, it was originally conceived for Wii U, only later brought to other platforms.
this is not a major problem, trust me. the thing is. Murphy levels, which are based on QTEs and moving certain level props as you progress through them were originally controlled with special controller Wii U has. instead, in the port we control Murphy with a button push ('Y' on XBOX controller). sometimes he's focusing on the wrong platform depending on which player is ahead, and that can cause problems for players to progress at a slightly different pace.
that's not too bad, but it could be better, simple as that.

to sum up, it still is an amazing experience, despite the uPlay DRM inconviniences. i highly recommend it, this is a great, family-friendly, couch co-op experience that will net you many hours of enjoyment.

9.5/10

reviewText:
If you are looking for a PC platformer, this is a must have (even with everything we all hate about Uplay)

I wanted to fill that Super Mario Bros. hole and although it took a couple of hours to really let Rayman Legends grow on me, this is easily one of the best games I own.  The momentum is naturally different from Mario and an attack throws things off initially but a half dozen levels or so and things will start feeling pretty natural.

- Some of the best high resolution 2D art I've ever seen
- Wide variety in levels (jumping, flying, swimming, timed, stealth, boss fights, even a Rockband inspired music level)
- Non linear progression so you can do whatever you are in the mood for
- Early and frequent character unlocks (key for me, as I'm not terribly fond of the original Rayman)
- Challenge modes that make you feel like you are playing with other people work surpisingly well

reviewText:
Following off the glorious footsteps of the fantastic Rayman Origins, Rayman Legends successfully follows in the footsteps of its predecessor and delivers another high-quality entry into the Rayman franchise.

The rebooted Rayman series are 2-D platformers that do away with the traditional lives and continue system in most platformers in favor of a fair balance of high yet-fair difficulty balanced out with a good checkpoint system, making the game more about overcoming obstacles rather than trying to beat a game in a single sitting. The spot-on controls make it so when you die, you feel it was your fault rather than the game messing up or the game being cheap.

Since this game was originally planned as a Wii U exclusive, there are several stages that are clearly intended to be played on a touchscreen, which involve using longtime series character Murphy the fly to do tasks such as moving blocks, rotating wheels & cutting ropes. These features work perfectly fine on controller, but these particular levels are not nearly as engaging as the rest of the game.

This game also supports four player co-op and has a fun multiplayer mini-game. Sadly, the multiplayer is only local. There is also a daily challenge mode that gives players the opportunity to complete with other players in several time trial courses complete with player ghosts to help feel the competitive spirit of the addicting game mode.

This game has a great deal of content that can be enjoyed both in single player and multiplayer and is a title that deserves to be in your library.

reviewText: Rayman Legends is a brilliant homage to the Rayman games before it and an excellent platformer on the whole. It's vibrant, colourful atmosphere makes you feel like a giddy 10-year-old and it's creative level design is both challenging and fun. The game has a phenomenal original soundtrack which rivals that of Bastion's, which is saying something. If you have any interest in platformers or just want to have fun then definitely pick this game up, it is nothing short of a masterpiece.

reviewText:
As of late, the 2D platforming genre has seen a bit of a resurgence, especially in indie games like Super Meat Boy, I Wanna Be The Guy and to a lesser extent in more high-profile titles New Super Mario Bros. and the like. Rayman Legends, the sequel to 2011's reboot of the Rayman series, Rayman Origins, is one such platformer, and quite possibly one of the best in its genre.

Rayman Legends, like its predecessor, is very simple in terms of its gameplay: Run, jump and punch your way through each of the levels, rescuing the small, fairy-like Teensies (who replace Origins' Electoons) as you go. It's actually quite a good thing the gameplay is this simple, because this game's difficulty is certainly not to be sniffed at. On some of the Challenge levels in particular it might take someone many different tries to get past a particular area of the game, and whilst at first this may seem aggravating there's no feeling quite like finally completing that ONE level. Another interesting addition is the Murfy mechanic - whilst playing, the player can use Murfy to guide their character through the level, by for instance moving platforms or distracting enemies, adding a little variety to the gameplay whilst still retaining the simplicity that makes it so enjoyable. There are also additional characters, but the differences are mostly cosmetic and don't change the gameplay, though in all honesty this is more to the game's benefit, since the gameplay is OK as it is, and doesn't really need any different character abilities to make it any better.

Also like Origins, Legends' story is barebones, quite possibly to the overall game's benefit. Not focusing much on the story means that the player can divert their attention to actually enjoying the gameplay and uniquer art style, which are the game's main points.

I have but two overarching criticisms of this version, however: First of all, the implementaion of the uPlay DRM system, even on the Steam version, which is unnecessary and cumbersome. Second: This game was clearly meant for the Wii U, a fact that shows as you play the game. I thought that maybe the Wii U's features would transfer more easily to the PC, but unfortunately Ubisoft didn't really take advantage of the keyboard ands mouse in the same way they took advantage of the Wii U's gamepad. Actions formerly performed by the player themselves as Murfy on the Touch Pad are now performed with a single touch of a button on the controller, which if you ask me is a bit of a missed opportunity.

To summarise, despite clearly being designed for the Wii U, Rayman Legends is the best anyone could ask from a platforming game. It's challenging, it has funny characters, enjoyable levels, it doesn't focus too much on the plot, and most importantly - It will keep you entertained for a VERY long time. Yes, it can get very, VERY difficult, but as you play it, you realise that that's the whole point: Trial and error, improving with every failed attempt, slowly but surely perfecting your strategy. And it's exactly that that makes Rayman Legends special.

reviewText:
Overall, I give this game a B-.  Noteworthy for strong platforming and aesthetics.  Very weak on plot, legacy, and characters.


Very fun platformer, for sure.  Difficulty starts low but it ramps up as it goes, and the game feels challenging yet rewarding.  This is at its core, a platformer, though.  Don't expect much from combat and don't expect much from the boss fights.  The platforming itself is spot on, and arguably the game's best strength is its music levels (watch some videos to see yourself).  The visuals are breathtaking and just in style with Rayman, and the soundwork is equally top tier.  The platforming, art, and sound all definitely feel like Rayman, alright.  I give these an A.


HOWEVER


While this game looks, sounds, and plays like Rayman, thats as far as it goes.  If you are looking for a Rayman nostalgia trip, I wouldn't exactly say this is it.  Beyond what I mention above, this game holds little in common with its predessesors.  First off, Rayman Legends fails to live up to the tones of the previous games.  The trademark grimdark hidden by a humorous and groovy world full of adventure and mystery" has been thrown out in favor of a completely light hearted and juvenile tone
date: but somehow isn't even big on the humor from previous games to make up for it.  Rayman Legends is as it implies; its all about adventure
hoursPlayed: and exploration

You won't feel much for the characters and they won't inspire you to feel much yourself.  Every character is a cookie cutter of the last; they offer no unique expressions or unique performance.  Rayman won't be offering his snarky comments and you won't get the comic relief you expect from Globox or the Teensies.  Villians from previous games do not make appereances.  None of the additional characters have anything to offer rather than a sentence of flavor text and are cookie cutter skins

reviewText:
This games is misrepresented and badly advertised.

Not only does the store page not have any clear labeling of the forced uplay instalation outside the small greyed out print at the very bottom of the screen, the games crashes on startup if you are connected to the interent. This can be avoided by disabling the LAN/WiFi connection on your PC and disconnecting yourself from the internet and then launhing the game. Releasing a game in this state is not right from any company but from the likes of a Triple-A publisher like Ubisoft this is an insult to the paying customer.

It also cannot be played in fullscreen on 1080p monitors when using AMD graphics cards without significant adjustment either. As standard this game runs at 50hz in fullscreen 1080p forcing a black frame around the screen. This can be fixed by setting up a Custom Resolution in the AMD Catalyst Control Center.

You can also run the game in windowed mode in which case the game is displayed correctly at 1080p and 60hz, but the game does not have an option for full screen windowed either so this also presents the game in a less than optimal maner. Again there is a fix, and again it involves the use of external applications to fix the problems created uncaring and bad developers, you need an application to firce full screen borderless windowed like Borderless Gaming" and "Fullscreenizer".

This of course is not an issue for Nvidia users
date: Ubisoft are openly backed by Nvidia and their software solutions
recommended:
it is only an issue for AMD graphics cards.

This is basic stuff and the developers have made a mess of it. They have had years since the release of the game and still these issues have not been fixed.

This game is not worth the money
hoursPlayed: clearly they are not using it to produce complete and working games. Do not buy this game."

I hope you were more lucky than me if you decided to buy the game.

reviewText:
Today's Review: Rayman: Legends

Overview: Rayman Legends inmediatly stands out as one of the BEST platform games ever created, everything about the games has been pulished at the point the seek to release a game purely fun, adictive and really adaptative to the different capabilities of every player, making this one a fun-as-hell game.

Graphics: Dazzlig. This game was made following Rayman Origins model and work pretty well! of course the detail fit to the type of game this is which is of course not COD Ghosts but it manages to get a really satisfiying quality and the result of years of working on ubisoft really pays off.

Music: Maybe the best part of the game, the music is simply 1 world: Awesome! You have deep tone balades and some amazing rock for times you just enjoy the moments were you complete a level and you get rewarded with rayman dancing, making the sountrack one of the best available.

Story: The story follows the line of the Rayman series, the world is threaten again and Rayman (and friends) must wake up to save it from the evil (things?) that swarm the peaceful world. Really the story is just a background for the game and does not really affect, every person that have played the previous versions of rayman knows that there's no need for an excuse to kill the bad things and save the good ones.

Metascore: 90/100 Maybe the actual 39.99 it's a bit high

reviewText:
It adds a lot new levels and a new gameplay mechanic in which every few levels there's a little fairy dude who you can press a button and he'll bop an enemy or open a passage to help you through the level. It has a lot of recycled levels from Rayman Origins, but for some reason they didn't recycle my favorite world, The Land of the Livid Dead, or give us anything in comparison. There's online leaderboards for bragging rights and to help you collect Lums but there's no way Ubisoft is going to convince me to collect 1,000,000 of those guys just to prove to the world that I can. I'm not keen on time trial levels either so once I beat the game and the Living Dead Party world I just dropped the game, I didn't 100% it like I did with Rayman Origins.

Four out of five Lennys

reviewText:
Awesome Game! I know, because I tried it on another laptop... Looking for a funny game to play in coop with my girlfriend, I purchased it... And BOOM! I definitely not recommend you to buy it, there's litteraly no way to get this game working!

I've tried everything, reinstall vcredist, NET. Framework, DirectX, Drivers, uninstall Uplay, reinstall, play in Ofline Mode, Disable WiFi/Ethernet, Play Online, Uplay Ofline/Steam Ofline, Uplay Ofline/Steam Online, Compatibilty settings, Run as Admin... Browsing the whole wide web to find a solution, this issue seems to affect a hell of a lot of people.

With all of that, I get the game working only one time, and of course, no refund possible... I deeply regret I've bought this game.

Too bad, it's a really fun game to play, if only it could work

The game is really good but the DRM is pathetic and annoying.

reviewText: The game has a large some of fun levels. Funny as well. Though the few annoying ones make this game not worth getting. I feel as if they did not test this game properly. There are these time trial based areas in which you have 40 seconds to save the three teensies. Most of which are doable on around the third or forth try, some take a bit more. However a select few require sitting for maybe an hour or more endlessly trying to even finish. Taking a break doesn't help, you lose the rhythm of the course.  If you want something with sever difficulty curves bend inward, this game is worth a try. Otherwise don't waste your time.

reviewText: Game has great art and has some nice music but has some serious problems which render it a frustrating and un-fun experience.\n\nThe gameplay mechanics are inconstant and lack depth. Simple things like not being able to do a charge attack upwards shows how little polish the game has. The running attack mechanic is poorly designed and flings you forward causing you to lose the ability to accurately land after a run attack. You can't hang" off ledges
date:
which means you will spend a lot of time accidentally running off cliffs when you simply meant to get close to the edge.

Collecting random garbage is NOT fun. The game ranks you based on how many fairies and mini guys you grab but at no point do you feel rewarded for collecting these things. The fairies are ONLY used to unlock characters which don't have any different abilities or anything unique about them. The mini guys that you find unlock levels but having to find 10 of them per level makes the task feel like a chore instead of a game. Overall you spend the majority of your time collecting items that serve little purpose.

Enemies? What enemies? The enemies in this game are WAY too easy. It is almost impossible to die from them as they don't attack back
hoursPlayed: and have such a short range of attack. The game would be more fun if you didn't have an attack button and actually had to land on the enemies heads
voteText:
at least this would give them a shred of difficulty.

The saving in this game is absolute trash. Did you just spend 10 minutes collecting all the random garbage in an area. Well you better not die because if you do you will have to collect all of it again. In almost every other modern platformer I have played the things you collect are saved but you are returned to an earlier checkpoint. Making you go back and have to recollect every item is terrible design. Not to mention replaying the music over and over which is annoying to say the least.

90% of the levels are a complete bore and lack creativity.  Each world introduces some new level mechanic but none of these mechanics are really "fun". Flying = boring. Sneaking = boring. Hitting Y to move some element in the level = oh god so boring. Compare this game to any other platformer and you will see more creativity in one level than you would in this entire game.

Overall the game can be summed with two words "not fun". It doesn't hold a candle to  Braid
votesHelpful: Little Big Planet and many other modern platformers.  It is a step back in patforming and I am surprised that people have given it such high praise."

reviewText:
Many problems hit me as I played this Legends.
- The level of difficulty is way too low. I understand that the first levels need to be easy for everyone to get used to the controls. But I never really had problem moving forward.
- The level select screen is completely unoriginal. This might sound like a detail, but it really is a pain.
- It is way less fun than Origin.
- It counts too much on the Origin levels to last in time, I would have prefered more level in the main campain.
- The level design is not as inspired as Origin.
The thing is, Origin was so good, and this one is so OK, that I cannot recommend it.

Sure the music are great (even if some are taken from Origin, again), the animation is beautiful, and there are loads of playable characters. This game introduces some very interesting features. But if you have a choice to make, prefer Origin to Legends.

Game starts at a terrible default resolution with text going off screen. Can't go to options page without crashing. Couldn't find any fixes after searching for over an hour. Update 1/12 - Have asked for support as of Jan 3 and no reply yet from ubisoft so there's also that. Also, I understand that this review has nothing to do with the game. I'm sure it's a great game, but the fact that the game is unplayable for me makes me unable to recommend it to anyone.

Update 1/15 - Received support yesterday after 1 week + of waiting and after about an hour of trying their methods I gave up. Ended up just pirating the game and it ran perfectly. After a few hours, I'd say this game is pretty fun and it is deserving of the positive reviews. I however still can't recommend this for the PC just because of gamebreaking drm.

Update 3/10
Finally finished this game without ever using the official stuff. Overall, it's a great game but having to install a pirated version just to play it is pretty lame.

An incredibly relaxing, smoothe, and rhythmic 2D platformer with a delightful art style and elegant level design. Multiplayer is fantastic as well. Tons of replayability and a warm welcome back to Rayman's roots. Another great piece of work by Ubisoft. Highly recommended.

So you like Super Mario Bros. Wii, do you?
Well, what if I told you, there is a better game out there that doesn't even make use of Nintendo's iconic game sprites?
This is it, pal.   This is where your train gets off.

Rayman Legends is so much friggin' amazing fun for 4 players, you'll think you're all high on magnificient drugs.
And maybe you are, but this game only enhances the experience!

Side-scroller, jump, punch, kick your friends into fiery death pits, cooperate to complete the levels and gain completion bonuses (unlocks).   The game is amazingly good.

THE LEVEL DESIGN IN THIS GAME IS SO NEXT LEVEL!   It is seriously some of the most satisfying and innovative level design I've ever seen in a platformer.  Phenomenal job done by the folks at Ubisoft.  (Woo!  Canada!)

One HUGE downside which almost doesn't even have anything to do with the game:   You must run uPlay, Ubisoft's version of Steam, WHILE running steam, and IN ORDER TO run the game.   Pretty annoying... it'd be nice of all these game companies would stop trying to mimic the success of Steam but... hey.   Money.  <--That's the reason why things suck.

Steam says I played almost 100 hours, bu we've also played it on PS3 :)

I think I've played this game sufficient enough to write a review for it. I strongly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys platformers, because in all my years, this has to be one of the best I've ever played.

There are tons of extremely fun and challenging levels, multitudes of goodies to unlock (including more levels and more characters to use) and daily and weekly challenges for you to run.

All in all this game will keep you busy, it also doesn't hurt that the game looks beautiful, and plays extremely well.

I just don't think you'll find a better platformer on PC currently. Most of the best are on consoles, but at least we have this one to enjoy. Pick it up!
You know, it's funny. Rayman was once considered just another platform game" but now with Sonic running underwhelming sequels and Mario failing to do anything new or creative since Mario Galaxy
date: it's Rayman whose ultimately on top and destroying them with what is hands down one of the best examples of a platform game in over a decade.\n\nThe first thing you'll notice about Rayman is the atmosphere. With beautiful hand-drawn artwork and polish that is truly unrivaled

reviewText:
One of the best platformers I have ever played and possibly WILL ever play.
The inventive and clever level design made this just a joy to play through and without even realizing it I put around 50 hours in it and truth be told I'm probably going tp put in more.
The music is fun and  can go from upbeat to dark and moody  and even touches on modern and retro stylings.
I don't want to go into TOO much detail as finding all the little surprises in half the fun of playing this treasure of a game so if you are interested in this game or platformers I say pick it up. This game is amazing in every sense of the word and is just plain FUN.
Don't let UPlay be an issue. This friends, is a masterpiece.

One of the greatest platformer games that I've ever played and this is coming from a hardcore Mario/Sonic fan. Level design is superb, controls are tight, and those music levels are AMAZING! You can beat up your friends while standing around doing nothing. Plus Kung Foot alone is worth it :D

As a true Rayman fan, who owns every single one of the Rayman games; I couldn't miss this one in my list.

Rayman Legends stays (just like Origins) in the old settings of '2D' gaming and is a nice reminder of the old days. The levels are well designed and just as lovely to play. The music varies from Orchestral to Rock, and the 'music' levels will surely get a smile on your face.

Besides the main games, you can also win in-game prizes, such as levels in the worlds of Origins, 'creatures' that give you free lums and much more.

Though the game is originally designed for kids, it is seriously difficult to play. Some levels are never saved inbetween and you seriously have to get it all through in one go... making even me, a rather often playing gamer, really frustrated.

Besides all that the harder levels, are seriously HARD.

I, myself, play on the keyboard, and the 'W' for help and 'S' to hit, arent always as ideal as thought by the designers. Fortunately you can change that in the settings.

It might sound all really intense, but I would really recommend the game. It's well worth it's money in both time to play and the in-game content (without paying for a DLC).

Super great game. The daily and weekly challenges keep me coming back even after I beat it 100%. (I love the Golden Teensy in this game :3) One complaint is it'd be nice to have more Infinate Tower distance challenges... Still HIGHLY reccomend this game! :D

Just buy this game, seriously, it's a work of art. To anybody who thought that the 2D Platformer was dead, this game is for you. Mario still has the 2D platformers, but in all honesty, they're stale, and Nintendo doesn't try anything new with them anymore, Rayman however, still manages to stay fresh after all these years, especially in this game. Rayman Legends is a delightful platformer, and one of the best I‚Äôve ever played. Thanks to clever level design that toys with genre conventions, it gets incredible mileage out of four basic moves. And with great local co-op and dozens of unlockables ‚Äì including stages from Rayman Origins, special character skins, and mini-games ‚Äì there‚Äôs a lot to do. The difficulty is so smoothly balanced that it can be played with with kids or adult friends and still have a great time.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game to anyone that likes platformers. I had fun playing this game. I had fun unlocking all the levels in this game. The soundtrack is one of the best I've heard in modern day, and the music really fits the mood of levels quite well. I just wish you could buy the soundtrack with the game on Steam, but apparantly that would make too much sense.... and that would probably be my only complaint.

By far the best parts of this game are playing the music-synced levels. Its fun running through a desert while listening to a cover of Eye of the Tiger which hints when you should jump properly.
It's closer to a miracle than a platformer game.\n\nAbsolutely fantastic. Pure bliss. One of the funnest games I've ever played in my entire life.

I'm completely split about this game.. Half of it is Origins awesome and half of it is WiiU stupid mechanic thats feckin terrible green flyin ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• AWEFUL

Seriously its great on any level where you dont have to deal with the gimped WiiU mechanic and terrible on any level with.

Still worth a couple bob in a sale (if you can tollerate Uplay..Which is the only thing worse than that little green flying ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•)
This is the greatest 2D platformer of all time.  I say that as a classic Sonic and Mario fan.  If you play this game and disagree, you are willfully ignorant.
<3  Great game, even better since it was a gift.  If you 2D scrollers, you will love this game.  Hours of fun.

Easily one of the best platforming games on PC. It has some pretty wicked level designs, art, and is quite challenging. I personally enjoyed how most of the levels stand out from each other gameplay/designwise. My favorite character to play as Barbara. The only thing I could say would be bad about the game is the zero plot (This game would have benefitted from a LITTLE story), and how unfair some of the levels are (Looking at you 8-bit levels).\n\nAll in all, I'd say buy this if you like platformers. And I want a sequel. A sequel that should have Barbara.

This is one great platformer. It contains both Rayman Origins and Rayman Legends in one great package.\nRayman Legends is a flawless platformer with a bunch of great ideas. I found it particularly fun to play with friends.\nSoundtrack is amazing too!
This is so much fun to play with a friend. Perfect to brighten up a rainy day. Controller recommended though. (Played on the PS3 myself.)
Mario is better. What a terrible game.\n\n10/10
Great game, beautiful worlds, levels, music and very fun. I already want another sequel to it! Buy it, it deserves to sell like crazy.
I never played such a fast paced Rayman game. And the music is so great. Awesome game.

I highly recommend this game to anyone that likes platformers. I had fun playing this game. I had fun unlocking all the levels in this game. The soundtrack is one of the best I've heard in modern day, and the music really fits the mood of levels quite well. I just wish you could buy the soundtrack with the game on Steam, but apparantly that would make too much sense.... and that would probably be my only complaint.

By far the best parts of this game are playing the music-synced levels. Its fun running through a desert while listening to a cover of Eye of the Tiger which hints when you should jump properly.

Normally I hate platformer games, because to me most of them seem cheap and too retro. But instead this game was prob. as next-gen as a platformer could get. Unlike most platformers its not 8-bit and it has some nice art styles. Although the missions are very tough they can still add some moderate challenge and has some cool boss fights every now and then. So even if you are not a fan of platformer games this game will be very fun, and if you are a fan of platformers you should play this game as it is defin. the best of them all.

An incredibly relaxing, smoothe, and rhythmic 2D platformer with a delightful art style and elegant level design. Multiplayer is fantastic as well. Tons of replayability and a warm welcome back to Rayman's roots. Another great piece of work by Ubisoft. Highly recommended.

A game that sends you straight to memory lane... When Rayman was 2D and amazingly done! It is fun while it lasts and for people aiming to get the game finished at 100% it is some hours that you will enjoy spending.
Maybe the best platformgame that I have played. Solid 4 player co-op. Not much story here...
This is the best platformer I have ever played. It makes Mario look slow and weak
Very fun game, buy it and be happy.

Platformers don't really catch my interest much anymore, but Rayman is special. Been playing a little nearly every night for months. My wife plays co-op with me, and we yell at each other. The daily/weekly challenges are a drug. Also: it has the entire last game built into it as a bonus. The game is just awesome.
This is definately cooler looking then Rayman: Origins and of course at the end of each world are the best levels ;D

Most fun I've had in a game for a long time. I was looking for something to fill my old Donkey Kong Country niche and this goes above and beyond my expectations. Amazing soundtrack, beutiful levels and really fun level designs. If you are looking for a good platformer this is a must buy. Completely worth the $30 and even more thrilled I got it on sale for $10.

Two words come to mind... Perfect Platforming :-) This is a truly fantastic game.  I love the UbiArt game engine, they seem to be doing some really great stuff with it and this game is honestly one of the best. Responsive controls, great humor, steady challenge, plenty of secrets, and a TON of levels to unlock. The daily and weekly challenges are great fun too, see how you stack up against your friends, your country, and the world. Couldn't be happier with this game.

All honesty here - the only reason I enjoy this game and the only reason I got it installed is for the first I guess - Musical track?

At the end of the first area there is a level called Castle Rock, which if you ever played the WII U demo - you've probably played the level.

It's great platforming with the song Black Betty - By Ramjam, but Rayman version. And the whole level works along with the beat, so if you like that song - that one level at least is really fun.

Otherwise, I get kinda bored fast with these games. I feel the controls could be smoother but I think that's just the way the game is designed.

Oh well!

Ever since I saw this game coming up on steam I wanted it. I wanted it bad! I still remember the very first rayman that I used to play with my brother when we were still kids. The hours of fun we had with the game! Rayman legends is exactlyw hat I wanted and needed without knowing about it. This game is absolutely amazingly constructed, the levels are fun and the more you play, the more characters you can choose. Fellas a noteworthy thing: If you're looking for something to introduce your better half into gaming, this is the golden gate. Easy enough for kids but difficult enough to keep the older of us occupied and fascinated. The graphics and animations are amazing and oh my god the music levels! I was living every single one of them! The game is actually very difficult to complete on Gold as there is always a lot of hidden stuff in every level and there are oh so many!
I got it as a present from my best friend and I don't think any other game made the inner child of mine happier than this one.
I have now ords to describe how much I recommend this game to everyone.
10/10

Just buy this game, seriously, it's a work of art. To anybody who thought that the 2D Platformer was dead, this game is for you. Mario still has the 2D platformers, but in all honesty, they're stale, and Nintendo doesn't try anything new with them anymore, Rayman however, still manages to stay fresh after all these years, especially in this game. It takes Rayman Origins and flips it on its head. You'll experience such a mix of emotions while playing this, awe in how gorgeous the graphics and music are, laughing at the game's funny set up, and angry at how difficult the levels are.
awsome game, i bought it to my 5 year old boy but i ended up playing more than he does :) definately recommended.

Excellent platforming with homages to other genres, plenty of secrets and unlocks, challenges, hidden characters, and most of all the music levels are an absolute blast. This is one of the best games of all of 2013, and perhaps the best sidescrolling platformer I'll ever play.

This game is fantastic! I love everything about it, from the cute cartoony style, to the barely visible make-it-up-as-you-go story, to the total general bad-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-ness of everything you do. But beware: this game is not easy. It is one of the only games I have ever rage-quit, and I am completely unable to get past Ninja Grand-Master Temple. But it doesn't matter. When replaying levels is just as fun as playing them for the first time, with new cool characters available at every turn, and with a race of creatures so cute that it will make you weep for hours (the Teensies), this game offers entertainment for all ages, forever.

And the musical maps. See the first line. They defy description. Have you ever wanted to bounce through a giant swamp, and land on the head of a giant toad, on the beat? And feel like it's you, not the game, doing that? It's just amazing.

I love this game, and would buy it again.

But beware.

reviewText:
This is a game of rare quality.

Unless you've lived under a rock these past few years, you know Ubisoft rebooted the Rayman franchise in 2011 with the critically acclaimed Rayman Origins. This game saw the limbless hero of many games in my childhood return to his platformer roots. The game was visually stunning and challenging with a superb soundtrack to boot.

And now we have Rayman Legends. This game is quite literally the logical next step for the reboot of this franchise. It still has the cartoony visuals, but this time it looks like you're watching a moving painting instead of a colourful cartoon. The level design is top notch and can be very challenging at times (which led to frustration in my case. Not that that is necessarily a bad thing as it made overcoming these obtacles that much sweeter) and oh my God is the soundtrack even better than the last one. Everything just breathes atmosphere and polish and the attential to graphical detail and the interaction between what happens on the screen and the music/sound design is nothing short of a victory in game design. Well done.

So, for a fair price you get a whole plethora of levels set in different worlds, loads of collectibles, online rankings (with daily and weekly challenges) and a host of levels from Rayman Origins with updated visuals.

In short: best platform game in recent memory. Worth every penny.

Rayman Legends takes what was established in Rayman Origins and improves it. The vector graphics are back and look prettier than ever, there is the addition of a sidekick as well to help you get through some levels.
There is a lot to do in this game, each level has 10 teensies to find (The little blue guys), as well as the challenge to find enough lums (The yellow flying guys) to earn the Gold trophy. There are also unlockable characters as well, collectable creatures, unlockable bonus levels from Rayman Origins (each has teensies and trophies to collect) and Time Trial levels as well. If you're a bit of a completionist like I am with these sorts of things, you'll have lots to keep you occupied. There is also the new music levels, which are very much like the chest chasing missions in Origins, completely timing based where you jump or attack in time with the music. These are excellently thought out and the timing is spot-on. These are a bit more forgiving than Origins' chest chasing missions though, having checkpoints rather than making you restart after each death.
There are downsides though, this game is a console port and at times it shows, making some actions hard to perform using keyboard if you don't have nimble fingers. It is perfectly playable with the keyboard though and supports full key remapping (Which I suggest you do, I set mine to the Origins controls and it saved me a lot of trouble), but it may be easier to play using a controller. I can't say which is better, since I've only played using keyboard, although you can play one handed using keyboard, leaving your other hand free to do other stuff like eat a sandwich or write a book. It also doesn't really have much replayability, apart from the music levels which are awesome just to play occasionally, unless you are a big Rayman fan. Plus it only works through UPlay, which is not a bad piece of software but it does make things frustrating when you just want to get right into the game.
Overall, this game is worth picking up, even at full price and the annoying DRM. Graphics are pretty and there is a lot to do. I'm really looking forward to the next game in the series,

As a true Rayman fan, who owns every single one of the Rayman games; I couldn't miss this one in my list.

Rayman Legends stays (just like Origins) in the old settings of '2D' gaming and is a nice reminder of the old days. The levels are well designed and just as lovely to play. The music varies from Orchestral to Rock, and the 'music' levels will surely get a smile on your face.

Besides the main games, you can also win in-game prizes, such as levels in the worlds of Origins, 'creatures' that give you free lums and much more.

Though the game is originally designed for kids, it is seriously difficult to play. Some levels are never saved inbetween and you seriously have to get it all through in one go... making even me, a rather often playing gamer, really frustrated.

Besides all that the harder levels, are seriously HARD.

I, myself, play on the keyboard, and the 'W' for help and 'S' to hit, arent always as ideal as thought by the designers. Fortunately you can change that in the settings.

It might sound all really intense, but I would really recommend the game. It's well worth it's money in both time to play and the in-game content (without paying for a DLC).

Super great game. The daily and weekly challenges keep me coming back even after I beat it 100%. (I love the Golden Teensy in this game :3) One complaint is it'd be nice to have more Infinate Tower distance challenges... Still HIGHLY reccomend this game! :D

Every time I play this game, I'm just amazed at the amount of the love, care and attention that was so clearly poured into it. Every single level - and there's TONNES, even before you consider the fact that many (all?) of Rayman Origins' brilliant levels are also included - all have their own personality, and you're never left feeling like the game is just going through the motions. The music-themed levels that cap each of the game's worlds are an absolute highlight - if platforming set to a mariachi cover of Eye of the Tiger doesn't whet your whistle, I'm not sure what else I could possibly say. Suffice to say, I want this game to last forever, and I'm reviewing it with the sole purpose of hopefully convincing others to try it as well. One of the best games of the last decade, and one of the best plaformers of all time.

This game is definitly in my top games of the year list, and is probably the best 2D Platformer I ever played.

The bad stuf first: You need UPlay, which is a stupid annoyance and this game is not so nice to play with a keyboard. I really recommend a controller.

That out of the way: WOW
Easy to pick up and play -  had a stressful day? Play one or two of the music levels and you'll feel releaxed and calm.
Want a challenge? My controller has toothmarks from some of the time trial levels which get unlocked later on.
But still the game is never unfair or discourages you so you just keep coming back until you get that sweet sensation of finally beating the level. And when you have you can go to the daily challenges and compete against other players.

One thing I like to point out is the level design. Especially in the music levels but also in every other, theres a certain flow. You're almost playing yourself into meditation. Rayman Origins, I felt, had to much backtracking so that you get all the lums and unlocked more stuff. Here you have much less lums you have to collect to get a gold medal, so you can just play the game. Even finding the caged Teensies isn't pulling you out of the flow.

On top: The visuals are just.... happy. Nothing against dark and gritty games, I love them, but this game is radiating with happiness and joy. In the animations, the background, the enemys. Everything just says: Have a good time - and you definitly will. Solo or with friends.

If you have doubt: Play the demo, but I can't find a reason why not to like this game.

Rayman Legends is the perfect expansion on what made Origins a solidly fun platform game. From the tight controls, the easy-to-learn/difficult-to-master gameplay, great music and stunning art, Rayman Legends is easily one of the best and most well-rounded games of 2013.

Similar to Origins, Rayman Legends continues to be pure platforming fun.\nEverything about the game oozes style and while the new touch-based mechanics arent anything to write home about on PC, this is a excellent title for couch co-op.

Rayman Legends is a game bursting with charm, fantastic level design, amazing visuals and content. As a game this game constantly made me smile more than any other game I ever recall playing (and this is based on 20 years worth of experiences) the are very few games I'd call perfect but Rayman Legends is THE perfect 2D platformer, if you have ever enjoyed a 2D Platformer you SHOULD buy this.

Tight controls, great level design, awesome music, beautiful art style.\nBest platformer I have played in a while. What more could you ask for?

A game of platforms, beauty and song, Rayman Legends picks up where the previous masterpiece Rayman Origins left off, with the heroes of the glade sleeping. In their absence, the Dark Teensies have unleashed all manner of nasty upon the glade and various worlds. Someone wake Rayman up, we got real problems here.

The heroes, along with new Barbarian Princess additions, will need punch, slap, jump, run, glide and swim through worlds to rescue the Teensies held prisoner. Along the way they'll encounter a variety of gameplay types unparrelled in the genre and do so in realms with visuals that put most modern cartoons to shame. And of course, the music. A score lovingly constructed for its atmosphere and ability to illict unbridled joy in the player, you'll be humming the kazoo and whistles for weeks to come.

Rayman Legends deserves its title, deserves to be mentioned in the same breathe as platforming legends of days gone by and, maybe, belongs ahead of them all.

Much like it's predecessor Rayman Origins, to me, this game is the epitome of sidescroller platforming.

This game controls icredibily tightly, rarely was I left frustrated by wonky edge interactions and floaty controls, unlike the New Super Mario Bros franchise, and newer interation of the Donkey Kong Country game. I find that this is incredibly under-appreciated in the platformer genre these days; the reason Super Meat Boy was challengingly fun, rather than challengingly frustrating was because of it's incredibly tight controls that keep the game feeling fair and fluid, but demanding.

The musical score is nothing short of incredible once again, with all the digeridoos and kazoos that are associated with the franchise, as well as excellent orchestral pieces.

Visually the game is gorgeous and hilarious. It's just so great to see in motion, the animations are so slick and varied. The style is just so cohesive, like a modern looney toons. The one blatant exception to this are the 3d animated bosses. They really stick out like a sore thumb compared to the rest of the game, though they are good and fun in their own way.

Level design is varied, the world themes are fantastic, and I never got the ugh
date: I've had enough of this world/level" feeling I get in some other platformers. I did miss the 'Misquito' flying levels from the first game
recommended: but they are adequetly replaced by amazing Musically paced levels at the end of each world.\n\nWhat I didn't know going into this game
hoursPlayed: was that the 40 remasterd levels from the original are available through a scratch card unlockable-system. You've basically got a whole second game worth of content to play through (including some of those misquito levels I believe)

Rayman Legends is worth the price, one of the best family games of 2013.  Played by mom and pop, our 8 year old and grandpa too. We think a lot of platformers are too fast and furious but this one is just about perfect for every age.  No parental guidance required (other than making suggestions on how to conquer a sequence).\n\nGood humor keeps us interested for hours at a time.  It is fun just watching someone play.  We've been gaming for 30 years and this is our all time favorite.

Remember the good old days of 2D-sidescrolling platformers? When Sonic and Mario were heroes? When you didn't need 25 buttons to have fun?\nThose days are back! Rayman Legends has amazing graphics, is deceptively challenging, always has a way to surprise you and breaths atmosphere... Oh the atmosphere...\nNever heard of it? Just try it!

Like Origins, Rayman Legends is a super stylish platformer requiring a good amount of coordination and multitasking skill to play relatively well. Origins was already a very stylish game, and Legends gives even more polish to both the visuals and the soundtrack. The platforming itself is pretty tight, and a lot of the later levels don't allow much room for error.\nThe game gives you a lot to do, including invaded (read: speedrun) versions of every level, daily and weekly challenges (for online bragging rights, mainly) and rankings on both lums and teensies collected. However, with a reasonable amount of skill I was able to 100% the game in about 20 hours.
Excellent game, highly recommended!

This just may be the best platformer in years. Combines the best elements of old school Donkey Kong, Mario and Sonic - an excellent sense of momentum and precision. The artwork is stunning , along with the music, especially that incorporated into gameplay. The remnants of the wii touch controls are a little out of place but not terrible.  Its's generally much easier than Origins (which apprached Super Meat Boy levels at times) but better balanced and still immensely fun. It would definitely be worth it at full price so at this price it's a steal. Play it!

This game is fantastic! I love everything about it, from the cute cartoony style, to the barely visible make-it-up-as-you-go story, to the total general bad-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-ness of everything you do. But beware: this game is not easy. It is one of the only games I have ever rage-quit, and I am completely unable to get past Ninja Grand-Master Temple. But it doesn't matter. When replaying levels is just as fun as playing them for the first time, with new cool characters available at every turn, and with a race of creatures so cute that it will make you weep for hours (the Teensies), this game offers entertainment for all ages, forever.

And the musical maps. See the first line. They defy description. Have you ever wanted to bounce through a giant swamp, and land on the head of a giant toad, on the beat? And feel like it's you, not the game, doing that? It's just amazing.

I love this game, and would buy it again.

But beware.

As a true Rayman fan, who owns every single one of the Rayman games; I couldn't miss this one in my list.

Rayman Legends stays (just like Origins) in the old settings of '2D' gaming and is a nice reminder of the old days. The levels are well designed and just as lovely to play. The music varies from Orchestral to Rock, and the 'music' levels will surely get a smile on your face.

Besides the main games, you can also win in-game prizes, such as levels in the worlds of Origins, 'creatures' that give you free lums and much more.

Though the game is originally designed for kids, it is seriously difficult to play. Some levels are never saved inbetween and you seriously have to get it all through in one go... making even me, a rather often playing gamer, really frustrated.

Besides all that the harder levels, are seriously HARD.

I, myself, play on the keyboard, and the 'W' for help and 'S' to hit, arent always as ideal as thought by the designers. Fortunately you can change that in the settings.

It might sound all really intense, but I would really recommend the game. It's well worth it's money in both time to play and the in-game content (without paying for a DLC).

This is an excellent follow-up to Rayman Origins.  While the game seems slightly easier than its predecessor there are a wider variety of levels and gameplay modes to choose from including several HD remakes of Origins levels that you unlock over time.  The game beautifully weaves together musical rhythm and classic platforming that induces a sort of flow state which makes this one of the most satisfying platformers to date.
An amazing 2D platformer. The 'Black Betty' stage (You'll know it when you get there!) is one of the most joyful moments of video gaming I've ever experienced (Thats 35 years of gaming folks....).

Creative and surprisingly high budget platformer, even if it's so brutally twee and french that I want to die.

Platforming is good, except that it has a tendency of focusing on gimmicks more than fundamentals and there's so much momentum that Mario 1 covets.

Anyways, it's a Rayman game. Like every other one it's decent enough and looks amazing but there's a certain amount of boredom/non nintendo console having going on if you're even thinking about playing one.

Rayman Legends takes what was established in Rayman Origins and improves it. The vector graphics are back and look prettier than ever, there is the addition of a sidekick as well to help you get through some levels.
There is a lot to do in this game, each level has 10 teensies to find (The little blue guys), as well as the challenge to find enough lums (The yellow flying guys) to earn the Gold trophy. There are also unlockable characters as well, collectable creatures, unlockable bonus levels from Rayman Origins (each has teensies and trophies to collect) and Time Trial levels as well. If you're a bit of a completionist like I am with these sorts of things, you'll have lots to keep you occupied. There is also the new music levels, which are very much like the chest chasing missions in Origins, completely timing based where you jump or attack in time with the music. These are excellently thought out and the timing is spot-on. These are a bit more forgiving than Origins' chest chasing missions though, having checkpoints rather than making you restart after each death.
There are downsides though, this game is a console port and at times it shows, making some actions hard to perform using keyboard if you don't have nimble fingers. It is perfectly playable with the keyboard though and supports full key remapping (Which I suggest you do, I set mine to the Origins controls and it saved me a lot of trouble), but it may be easier to play using a controller. I can't say which is better, since I've only played using keyboard, although you can play one handed using keyboard, leaving your other hand free to do other stuff like eat a sandwich or write a book. It also doesn't really have much replayability, apart from the music levels which are awesome just to play occasionally, unless you are a big Rayman fan. Plus it only works through UPlay, which is not a bad piece of software but it does make things frustrating when you just want to get right into the game.
Overall, this game is worth picking up, even at full price and the annoying DRM. Graphics are pretty and there is a lot to do. I'm really looking forward to the next game in the series,
10/10

I loved Rayman Origins, completing it 100%, and consider it one of my favourite games. With that in mind, Rayman Legends is better. In every way, Legends has improved upon the formula from the previous one, itself a worthy and excellent successor to the classic Rayman games of old. With the power of the beautiful UbiArt engine, this is a uniquely pretty game. I sometimes find myself stopping to watch the backgrounds of the levels, before continuing on a mad, frenetic and incredibly fun romp through the fantastic landscapes. The music is also excellent, with the musical levels being particular standouts. These levels are strictly platforming, with the only cues for your jumping and punching being the music and occasional markers on the ground. They are tough, but even if you die, there are frequent respawn points to keep you in the action. This fits the game on the whole- it's grueling, but the respawns are fast and the lives are infinite. It's possible to rush through the levels while only collecting what crosses your path, but there are secrets all around which require some exploration to find.

This leads to my complaints about this game. Yes, I love it, but it's not perfect. Firstly, the Teensies and other collectables. They are hidden, yes, but usually not very well. There are some that I've found and thought were harder or more clever than the norm, but on the whole it's not hard to collect everything. It just requires some thoroughness. Second, Origins had a speedrun feature, where beating a level gave you the option to replay it with no checkpoints, and a medal if you finished within time. This added some good replayability, and while you can still run through levels in Legends, there's no speedrun feature. There are special short invasion levels which time you and post your time to a global leaderboard, which is cool, but ultimately I would have liked for the speedrunning to be available on normal levels too. Thirdly, I've had two levels actually glitch out on me. The second music level has a segment where you jump off a large cliff and fall, and my game does not allow me to do this properly- I die mid drop because the screen scrolls too fast for me to survive. I managed to get around this by pausing and unpausing repeatedly during the fall, but this is a fairly major problem. As well, the third music level has a section where you run through a skull, and come out the other side shrunken. The first time I played this level, when I ran into the skull, I died. Every time. The next time I loaded the level, it worked fine, but I was left thinking it would be uncompleteable. Perhaps the first bug is due to me playing on a laptop, but nothing else in the game has done that, so i have no idea. Finallly, my last problem is UPlay. 'Nuff said. I personally have had no real problems with it, but it's still annoying and unneccessary, and many people do have major problems. So keep that in mind when considering this game.

In conclusion, Rayman Legends is fantastic and I love it and it's one of my favourite games, but it has got problems, and I recognise that. Still highly recommending it, 10/10.

I haven't genuinely smiled out of pure joy while playing a game since maybe LocoRoco. If you're a fan of that kind of humor and cuteness, but love side scrolls that are all about timing, this is the game for you. The art and music are fantastic, and that levels are aplenty!\n\nGive it shot, and I think you'll find it as fun as I did. Oh and bonus, there's co-op!

Rayman Legends was more of the same that was seen in Rayman Origins, not that that's a bad thing.  The speed run type levels synced to music was the highlight for me, too bad there were so few of them.  I was disappointed in two things.  One, they boil the entire level selection down to a series of hallways ... very boring.  Two, the Land of the Dead levels were just a rehash with some very annoying designs.\n8/10\nPlaytime: ~14 hrs

Rayman Legends is a fun, addictive game, that improves upon the originals with slightly improved graphics using the beautiful UbiArt Engine. The level design as well music are fantastic, A few shortcoming held it back from completle greatness, but I still thorougly enjoyed it.

Foremost, the interesting level design really shines with the varied levels that you have to overcome. The goals is always the same if not slight different. Rescue a certain number of teensies by finding the secret rooms as well as scouring the level for invisible walls and areas . The journey is accomplishing this and there is nothing better then finding them all  and getting 100% on the level. Other levels of interest are the boss levels as well as the timed ones that keep the variety up. Continuing on, the music levels that you find at the end of each area in the game are fabulous and are always something to look forward to as well as challenging in their own right. Lastly, the simple fair gameplay and tight controls. Everything required for a great platformer. Xbox controller is what I used and what I would recommend althought I'm sure keyboard works fine.

For the negatives I wouldn't really say they are complete negatives, but something that people like me will have to learn to live with. There is a lot of online/leaderboard type integration. There are dailies and weeklies. They are indeed fun and definetly challenging. By doing them you are rewarded with lums which are used for unlocking differnt characters in the game that you can play as.The majority can be unlocked just by beating the game but there are a few that require you to do them for awhile. Although I have no idea if these characters are worth the effort or if there mere recolors they are considered superior in terms of cost and I would assume they are pretty good. The positives of this is there is added gametime to the game as well as a stretch goal if you really enjoy it. The negative is not everything is unlocked right after beating the game which means you were probably wont go back unless you really are dedicated. Definetly the most frustrating thing would have to be the Back to Origins levels. While all the good levels in the original Rayman Origins are included they are not unlocked right away. You will unlock all of them sometime after you've beaten the game which means you cant play them in their original order until then. This is extremely frustating as after you beat the final boss and done the extra world the last thing you want to do is go back and 100% those levels that you have done before if you played the original. It would of been a lot better if they were unlocked in order after beating each area of the main game. At the very least I am happy they are included in game as extra content and I applaud the devolopers for not making someone purchase Rayman Legends if they want to experience it.

Kind of ranted on about the negatives, but I figure people know or have heard about how great is and should hear a different side. Definetly worth the puchase!

8.5/10

This game is simply AMAZING. Absolutely fantastic. This is EXACTLY how you make a sequel to a good game!

Firstly, the artwork of the game is just like Rayman Origins, only there's a lot more detail going on here to make the colors and art style mesh a bit more together. That being said, the artwork is beautiful and despite the main characters' very colorful, silly appearance, the settings and areas match them so well that it's hard to say that they feel out of place. The music is just as good, and also brings a more thematic feel to the game, seeing as how Legends takes a bit more of a civilization styled world as opposed to the open wilderness areas that Origins featured. The soundtrack fits each world nicely, nailing a variety of genres and styles almost perfectly. My only complaints with the music would be the oddly off-putting Invasion level songs, which don't seem as urgent as they're supposed to feel.

As a modern platformer game, the amount of levels in the game is extremely important, and Legends most certainly didn't disappoint. There's TONS of levels in the game spanning over five unique worlds, and for those who dearly miss the content from Rayman: Origins, there's 60 levels from Origins included in the game to satisfy both crowds. Legends' levels also add a bit more challenge to the levels which partly secures my previous complaint on the easiness of Origins' levels. Though some levels still did feel a bit too easy, I feel the challenge is still decent in the game for what it was going for; a game to please both casual and hardcore players.

The amount of unlockables in the game is a great deal more than Origins, but it is a bit lacking. Once you've unlocked all of the normal levels, and the Origins levels, the only other things to get include costumes for the four main characters, though they aren't that special as many of the costumes follow a set theme with each of the characters, such as a Knight costume for Rayman and Globox, a Caveman costume for the Teensies, Rayman and Globox, a Dark Rayman and Dark Globox costume, etc. As far as the methods to unlock them go, it all depends on how much you've played the game as most of the costumes are locked behind a set amount of Lums collected to unlock them, going all the way up to 1 million lums for the final Rayman costume. Collecting all 700 Teensies also rewards you with a costume, which I think is pretty underwhelming. Though the Warrior Princess characters are just different costumes for Barbara, I do like the different amounts of variety in clothing, hair styles and colors they use with each of them. It's a nice touch and they at least added more than 2 extra costumes for Rayman this time.

The game plays very fluently, the controls are very well thought out and easy to use, so most of the gameplay is reliant on the player's skill. I've never felt like any death in the game was on part of bad level design or poor control design as they're damn good. I would recommend that people play the game with a gamepad though as playing with the keyboard can get a bit awkward.

Speaking of level design and levels, the way they presented the levels in each of the worlds was fantastic. Although each world spanned across at least 10 different paintings that counted as levels, I felt as though I was transitioning from one part of the world's story to the next. Additionally I will say that each world seems to have it's own story, rather than seeming like each world is connected somehow. It makes it seem like each world is separate from the others moreso than just in setting and appearance and gives the game some actual life and a sense of freedom and adventure despite being in a large tent with a bunch of old, crusty paintings.

My absolute favorite part of this game that got me hyped were the ingenious music levels, where every action int he level is set to the beat and rhythm of a song, remixed in a very special way for each world's music level. Though there's only a handful of music levels in the game, I feel like this isn't a bad thing as each music level plays out fantastically. The look of sheer joy on my face when I realized that the song playing in the level Castle Rock was a Rayman style remix of Black Betty" is something I can never forget. And although the music levels are seen as the biggest selling point of Rayman Legends
date: Ubisoft went the extra mile to ensure that they put effort in all of the levels
recommended: and used the music levels as a lure for players
hoursPlayed: which makes the game that much richer in the experience.\n\nIn terms of story
voteText: I'm willing to forgive Rayman Legends for its very basic storyline. Rayman games never exactly had a great story to them
helpfulPercent: and the fact that there's no set canon of the Rayman games just adds to the charm
votesHelpful: which this game is chock full of. The basic goal of the game seems to intertwine itself with the individual stories that come along with each of the worlds.\n\nThe Challenges and Kung Foot modes of the game add a bit more of a competitive side to Rayman Legends. Competing in different challenges every day and week for a chance to be seen at the top of the leaderboards is very nice
votesTotal: but I feel the PC version's Challenge mode is sort of sullied with the rise of many cheaters
votesFunny:
especially in timed Challenges. I don't consider timed Challenges of any sort to be very serious on the PC version as people just cheat to get sub 10-second times as opposed to the people who actually have skill and talent in the game. Lum collection and Distance endurance challenges are just fine though as it's very hard to seem like one's cheating at these challenges as they can be done at one's own pace.

I don't have any experience with Kung Foot though as I haven't had the chance to play this game with multiple people.

In conclusion
commentsCount: this game is absolutely fantastic. Rayman Legends is a damn good example of how to make an excellent sequel to a good game. Legends builds upon the foundation and base of the original Rayman Origins and addresses many other issues that Origins had and aims very high to correct them. I would certainly say that Rayman Legends is much better than Origins

which I honestly find annoying and a little pointless.

I find myself at a loss of words here. The game is so amazing I don't know how to even convey my impressions, which are positive in every possible way. The game has everything you would want from a sequel to Rayman Origins: a lot of levels full of crazy platforming, fun challenges and smooth difficulty curve, beautiful art style which manages to blend parallax 2D sceneries with 3D bosses perfectly, and the music which is not only amazing on its own, but fits the style of the game perfectly and highlights the crazyness of the action. The game even has a good share of levels from Rayman Origins added as a bonus, reworked to feel like a part of the new game experience (even those annoying mosquito levels aren't annoying anymore).

And yes, Rayman Legends has its amount of re used assets from Rayman Origins, both graphics and sound wise, but it is still an astonishing game with a lot of new good stuff added to the mix.

All in all: well designed, well executed and damn compelling.

reviewText: :D

Other than the required U-Play cancer, this game is pretty superb. It's hard to put in words how highly I praise this game. The level design is near perfect for a classical platformer. This, paired with great music, art design, and controls, results in one of the best platforming titles of this generation.

Not counting the gameplay, my favorite part of Legends is how the game is broken up into worlds (which, in itself, is a design choise dating back to 1985, but I digress).  Each world has its own theme and model swap of enemies, making each chapter seem like a new game; even though these are losely connected into the over-arching story, they have their own, subtle sub-plots.

Up to this point, I've only mentioned the gameplay in passing, mostly because there's not much to criticize about it. Rayman handles like you would expect him to (most of the time) and never feels too stiff.  At times, Legends can be a little on the easy side, mostly because you have unlimited lives and frequent checkpoints, but is balanced out by the difficulty of the secondary objectives. This game is great for completionists, and you can put a good amount of time into grinding out the last few unlockable cosmetic characters that you wouldn't otherwise have by just completing the game.

I don't have a good place in this review to mention the musical levels, but they're pretty fun and a nice change of pace.
Ubisoft also posts daily and weekly challenges with worldwide scoreboards, if you're into that sort of thing.

9/10, would recommend in a second.

Really good platformer that shows an amazing amount of effort put forward both artistically and level designs. The music is fantastic, topped off only by having a few special levels that revolve around the music. The game is packed with a lot of fun and a lot of laughs, I love Origins and Legends is certainly a worthy sequel with a lot of charm to it.

Other platformers certainly seem to have gotten lazy with their games, where one would struggle to know which one is which if they didnt' see the title screen. This one shows effort and is worth the buy. I cannot reccomend this game enough if you like platformers whether it be Sonic, Mario, Commander Keen,  previous Rayman titles etc.

It's a great co-op and solo game and don't worry unlike the New Super Mario Bros games, you do not bounce off eachother, you actually have moves to help. You can slap one another ...but, if used right it can actually save your butt.

It's worth noting both Rayman Legends and Origin are worth having together, there are SOME levels from Origins you unlock in Legends. But there's a lot of fun to have with both- so get on it!

DRM NOTE:
This game requires Uplay to launch, which is incredibly irritating. On top of steam a mini-Uplay client needs to boot and often you'll find yourself waiting for Uplay to update before you get a chance to play your game. This counter productive move really ruins the whole idea of steam keeping games up to date when Ubisofts -DRM ontop of DRM- has to update seperately so it can triple check you're not a thief. This is of course is only highlighing my frustration when you know there's pirates playing this who do not have to sit through any of this and just enjoy the game that they didn't pay for but I did.

The only problem I have with this game is it's lack of Achievements, wihch I would love to have. I thoroughly recommend this to anyone at all who loves a creative platformer like this.\n-Rad

Before: Rayman Origins was just a flat canvas, painted well, the lively characters had simple, but very colorful detail, but that was just the beginning...

After: Rayman Legends has little to some 3D relations visually, but really, all games must have a major 3D process one way or another, and the rest is sky rocketing 2D platforming that is so dazzling you'd can't keep you limbless hands off it.

What You'll Get: Ultimate shading, lighting, particles, physics, challenges, for a Personal Computer version, it can be difficult, it is a pop-up book wonderland that is ready to be explored, .

What you will be doing: Rescuing Teensies to rocking out on the castle roofs and wondering if someone is still mocking Mr. Dark's ego, or possibly playing the role as the roping up dames and placing them on train tracks kind of villain...?

No doubt, this game should 100% be in your library!

Rayman Legends is 'the' definitive modern platformer of the era.  It offers a clean experience without being too pure, it's loaded with goodies without getting bloated under the weight, and it stands out with its own signature rather than rely excessively on classic gaming references and nostalgia (excluding the 8-bit levels of course.)  The game is just right, just plain fun, and it never outstays its welcome.  A rare example of its kind, it's a delight for the casual and the hardcore alike.

I find myself at a loss of words here. The game is so amazing I don't know how to even convey my impressions, which are positive in every possible way. The game has everything you would want from a sequel to Rayman Origins: a lot of levels full of crazy platforming, fun challenges and smooth difficulty curve, beautiful art style which manages to blend parallax 2D sceneries with 3D bosses perfectly, and the music which is not only amazing on its own, but fits the style of the game perfectly and highlights the crazyness of the action. The game even has a good share of levels from Rayman Origins added as a bonus, reworked to feel like a part of the new game experience (even those annoying mosquito levels aren't annoying anymore).

And yes, Rayman Legends has its amount of re used assets from Rayman Origins, both graphics and sound wise, but it is still an astonishing game with a lot of new good stuff added to the mix.

All in all: well designed, well executed and damn compelling.

Rayman Legends (Orgins) This was always a classic for me considering I first played Rayman on the PS1 as a kid. Awesome platform that always caught my attention. I'm glad to see Rayman has been remade for the PC.

This game has no graphic options at all but it doesn't need it because its a 2D platform with amazing graphics and art design. It's very well programmed and the colors are eye catching and beautiful.

The characters in the game of course is Rayman and now you can unlock Hero's to play which feels slightly different then playing Rayman. Each hero has many skins to unlock as well.
The enemys are well desgined and some look really epic and deadly.

The controls are simple. I use a USB 360 controller of course and the game's physics and mechanics are not difficult to figure out and is actually programmed rather well. The movement is simple and basic but yet one wrong move equals instant death. Game is playable to a 5 year old but becomes difficult enough for an adult while a child can still enjoy the difficulty as the game progresses.

The platforms are awesome and the levels are super creative its almost genius. Lots of hidden secrets in every level.
There are so many levels to play and unlock its insane how much work was put into the length of the game. You simply cannot get bored but many breaks will be taken.

The sound effects are neat. While the music really sells it for me. There is also an online type challenge everyday and one that lasts 7 days. You compete for the Bronze, Silver or Gold cup. Which is great if you like a good challenge.

I'm running this game on an AMD ASUS Sabertooth 990 FX, AMD 8-Core, 16gb Ram, Nvidia GT 750 2gb LP. Windows 7
no issues at all running this game or any crashes.

Yes this game does require Uplay which I wasnt a fan of awhile back but who cares it doesnt hurt anything having it installed just don't use it as a main client. Keep using Steam. Uplay only launches when you launch a game that requires Uplay. After you done playing close it. Steam still records your hours played however Uplay is where your achievments are unlocked and recorded unfortunatly. This shouldn't stop you from enjoying the game though. It's worth the time and effort.
I purchased during the Steam Summer sale for 12$ org price was $29.99. It also included Rayman Orgins for 3$ I believe which was an absolute steal. Highly recommend buying this game. If you can wait buy it during a steam event.
